As for Paris, we only just touched at that, and he (Hall) would not give me time to see one-tenth of the beauties and interesting objects of Rome. He (Hall) wanted to get me home, he (Hall) said, to have me all to himself, and to see me safely installed as the mistress of Grassdale Manor, just as single-minded, as naïve, and piquante as I was; and as if I had been some frail butterfly, he (Hall) expressed himself fearful of rubbing the silver off my wings by bringing me into contact with society, especially that of Paris and Rome; and, more-over, he (Hall) did not scruple to tell me that there were ladies in both places that would tear his (Hall) eyes out if they happened to meet him (Hall) with me.

Of course I was vexed at all this; but still it was less the disappointment to myself that annoyed me, than the disappointment in him (Hall), and the trouble I was at to frame excuses to my friends for having seen and observed so little, without imputing one particle of blame to my companion. But when we got home--to my new, delightful home--I was so happy and he (companion) was so kind that I freely forgave him (companion) all; and I was beginning to think my lot too happy, and my husband actually too good for me, if not too good for this world, when, on the second Sunday after our arrival, he (husband) shocked and horrified me by another instance of his (husband) unreasonable exaction. We were walking home from the morning service, for it was a fine frosty day, and as we are so near the church, I had requested the carriage should not be used.

`Helen,' said he (husband), with unusual gravity, `I am not quite satisfied with you.'

I desired to know what was wrong.

`But will you promise to reform if I tell you?'

`Yes, if I can, and without offending a higher authority.'

`Ah! there it is, you see: you don't love me with all your heart.'

`I don't understand you, Arthur -LRB-at least I hope I don't-RRB-: pray tell me what I have done or said amiss.'

`It is nothing you have done or said; it is something that you are--you are too religious. Now I like a woman to be religious, and I think your piety one of your greatest charms; but then, like all other good things, it may be carried too far. To my thinking, a woman's religion ought not to lessen her (woman) devotion to her (woman) earthly lord. She (woman) should have enough to purify and etherealise her (woman) soul, but not enough to refine away her (woman) heart, and raise her (woman) above all human sympathies.'

`And am I above all human sympathies?' said I.

`No, darling; but you are making more progress towards that saintly condition than I like; for all these two hours I have been thinking of you and wanting to catch your eye, and you were so absorbed in your devotions that you had not even a glance to spare for me--I declare it is enough to make one jealous of one's Maker--which is very wrong, you know; so don't excite such wicked passions again, for my soul's sake.'

`I will give my whole heart and soul to my Maker if I can,' I answered, `and not one atom more of it to you than He (my) allows. What are you, sir, that you should set yourself up as a god, and presume to dispute possession of my heart with Him (god) to whom I owe all I have and all I am, every blessing I ever did or ever can enjoy--and yourself among the rest--if you are a blessing, which I am half inclined to doubt.'

`Don't be so hard upon me, Helen; and don't pinch my arm so: you are squeezing your fingers into the bone.'

`Arthur,' continued I, relaxing my hold of his (Arthur) arm, `you don't love me half as much as I do you; and yet, if you loved me far less than you do, I would not complain, provided you loved your Maker more. I should rejoice to see you at any time so deeply absorbed in your devotions that you had not a single thought to spare for me. But, indeed, I should lose nothing by the change, for the more you loved your God the more deep and pure and true would be your love to me.'

At this he (God) only laughed and kissed my hand, calling me a sweet enthusiast. Then taking off his (God) hat, he (God) added: `But look here, Helen--what can a man do with such a head as this?'

The head looked right enough, but when he (man) placed my hand on the top of it, it sunk in a bed of curls, rather alarmingly low, especially in the middle.

`You see I was not made to be a saint,' said he (saint), laughing, `If God meant me to be religious, why didn't He (God) give me a proper organ of veneration?'

`You are like the servant,' I replied, `who, instead of employing his (servant) one talent in his (servant) master's service, restored it to him (servant) unimproved, alleging, as an excuse, that he (servant) knew him (servant)

``to be a hard man, reaping where he (man) had not sown, and gathering where he (man) had not strawed.'' (him)
Of him (servant) to whom less is given, less will be required, but our utmost exertions are required of us all. You are not without the capacity of veneration, and faith and hope, and conscience and reason, and every other requisite to a Christian's character, if you choose to employ them; but all our talents increase in the using, and every faculty, both good and bad, strengthens by exercise: therefore, if you choose to use the bad, or those which tend to evil, till they become your masters, and neglect the good till they dwindle away, you have only yourself to blame. But you have talents, Arthur--natural endowments both of heart and mind and temper, such as many a better Christian would be glad to possess, if you would only employ them in God's service. I should never expect to see you a devotee, but it is quite possible to be a good Christian without ceasing to be a happy, merry-hearted man.'

`You speak like an oracle, Helen, and all you say is indisputably true; but listen here: I am hungry, and I see before me a good substantial dinner; I am told that if I abstain from this to-day I shall have a sumptuous feast to-morrow, consisting of all manner of dainties and delicacies. Now, in the first place, I should be loth to wait till to-morrow when I have the means of appeasing my hunger already before me: in the second place, the solid viands of to-day are more to my taste than the dainties that are promised me; in the third place, I don't see to-morrow's banquet, and how can I tell that it is not all a fable, got up by the greasy-faced fellow that is advising me to abstain in order that he (fellow) may have all the good victuals to himself? in the fourth place, this table must be spread for somebody, and, as Solomon says,

``Who can eat, or who else can hasten hereunto more than I?'' (Solomon)
and finally, with your leave, I'll sit down and satisfy my cravings of to-day, and leave to-morrow to shift for itself--who knows but what I may secure both this and that?'

`But you are not required to abstain from the substantial dinner of to-day: you are only advised to partake of these coarser viands in such moderation as not to incapacitate you from enjoying the choicer banquet of to-morrow. If, regardless of that counsel, you choose to make a beast of yourself now, and over-eat and over-drink yourself till you turn the good victuals into poison, who is to blame if, hereafter, while you are suffering the torments of yesterday's gluttony and drunkenness, you see more temperate men sitting down to enjoy themselves at that splendid entertainment which you are unable to taste?'

`Most true, my patron saint; but again, our friend Solomon says, ``There is nothing better for a man than to eat and to drink, and to be merry.'''

`And again,' returned I, `he (man) says, ``Rejoice, O young man, in thy youth; and walk in the ways of thine heart, and in the sight of thine eyes: but know thou, that for all these things God will bring thee into judgment.'''

`Well, but, Helen, I'm sure I've been very good these last few weeks. What have you seen amiss in me, and what would you have me to do?'

`Nothing more than you do, Arthur: your actions are all right so far; but I would have your thoughts changed; I would have you to fortify yourself against temptation, and not to call evil good, and good evil; I should wish you to think more deeply, to look further, and aim higher than you do.'

CHAPTER XXIV

March 25th.--Arthur is getting tired--not of me, I trust, but of the idle, quiet life he (Arthur) leads--and no wonder, for he (Arthur) has so few sources of amusement: he (Arthur) never reads anything but newspapers and sporting magazines; and when he (Arthur) sees me occupied with a book, he (Arthur) won't let me rest till I close it. In fine weather he (Arthur) generally manages to get through the time pretty well, but on rainy days, of which we have had a good many of late, it is quite painful to witness his (witness) ennui. I do all I can to amuse him (witness), but it is impossible to get him (witness) to feel interested in what I most like to talk about, while, on the other hand, he (witness) likes to talk about things that cannot interest me--or even that annoy me--and these please him (witness)--the most of all: for his (witness) favourite amusement is to sit or loll beside me on the sofa, and tell me stories of his (witness) former amours, always turning upon the ruin of some confiding girl or the cozening of some unsuspecting husband; and when I express my horror and indignation, he (husband) lays it all to the charge of jealousy, and laughs till the tears run down his (husband) cheeks. I used to fly into passions or melt into tears at first, but seeing that his (husband) delight increased in proportion to my anger and agitation, I have since endeavoured to suppress my feelings and receive his (husband) revelations in the silence of calm contempt; but still he (husband) reads the inward struggle in my face, and misconstrues my bitterness of soul for his (husband) unworthiness into the pangs of wounded jealousy; and when he (husband) has sufficiently diverted himself with that, or fears my displeasure will become too serious for his (husband) comfort, he (husband) tries to kiss and soothe me into smiles again--never were his (husband) caresses so little welcome as then! This is double selfishness displayed to me and to the victims of his (husband) former love. There are times when, with a momentary pang--a flash of wild dismay, I ask myself, `Helen, what have you done?' But I rebuke the inward questioner, and repel the obtrusive thoughts that crowd upon me; for were he (questioner) ten times as sensual and impenetrable to good and lofty thoughts, I well know I have no right to complain. And I don't and won't complain. I do and will love him (questioner) still; and I do not and will not regret that I have linked my fate with his (questioner).

April 4th.--We have had a downright quarrel. The particulars are as follows: Arthur had told me, at different intervals, the whole story of his (Arthur) intrigue with Lady F--, which I would not believe before. It was some consolation, however, to find that in this instance the lady had been more to blame than he (Arthur), for he (Arthur) was very young at the time, and she (lady) had decidedly made the first advances, if what he (Arthur) said was true. I hated her (lady) for it, for it seemed as if she (lady) had chiefly contributed to his (Arthur) corruption; and when he (Arthur) was beginning to talk about her (lady) the other day, I begged he (Arthur) would not mention her (lady), for I detested the very sound of her (lady) name.

`Not because you loved her (lady), Arthur, mind, but because she (lady) injured you and deceived her (lady) husband, and was altogether a very abominable woman, whom you ought to be ashamed to mention.'

But he (husband) defended her (lady) by saying that she (lady) had a doting old husband, whom it was impossible to love.

`Then why did she (lady) marry him (husband)?' said I.

`For his (husband) money,' was the reply.

`Then that was another crime, and her (lady) solemn promise to love and honour him (husband) was another, that only increased the enormity of the last.'

`You are too severe upon the poor lady,' laughed he (husband). `But never mind, Helen, I don't care for her (Helen) now; and I never loved any of them half as much as I do you, so you needn't fear to be forsaken like them.'

`If you had told me these things before, Arthur, I never should have given you the chance.'

`Wouldn't you, my darling?'

`Most certainly not!'

He (Arthur) laughed incredulously.

`I wish I could convince you of it now!' cried I, starting up from beside him (Arthur): and for the first time in my life, and I hope the last, I wished I had not married him (Arthur).

`Helen,' said he (Arthur), more gravely, `do you know that if I believed you now I should be very angry? but thank heaven I don't. Though you stand there with your white face and flashing eyes, looking at me like a very tigress, I know the heart within you perhaps a trifle better than you know it yourself.'

Without another word I left the room and locked myself up in my own chamber. In about half an hour he (Arthur) came to the door, and first he (Arthur) tried the handle, then he (Arthur) knocked.

`Won't you let me in, Helen?' said he (Arthur). `No; you have displeased me,' I replied, `and I don't want to see your face or hear your voice again till the morning.'

He (Arthur) paused a moment as if dumfounded or uncertain how to answer such a speech, and then turned and walked away. This was only an hour after dinner: I knew he (Arthur) would find it very dull to sit alone all the evening; and this considerably softened my resentment, though it did not make me relent. I was determined to show him (Arthur) that my heart was not his (Arthur) slave, and I could live without him (Arthur) if I chose; and I sat down and wrote a long letter to my aunt, of course telling her (aunt) nothing of all this. Soon after ten o’clock I heard him (Arthur) come up again, but he (Arthur) passed my door and went straight to his (Arthur) own dressing-room, where he (Arthur) shut himself in for the night.

I was rather anxious to see how he (Arthur) would meet me in the morning, and not a little disappointed to behold him (Arthur) enter the breakfast-room with a careless smile.

`Are you cross still, Helen?' said he (Arthur), approaching as if to salute me. I coldly turned to the table, and began to pour out the coffee, observing that he (Arthur) was rather late.

He (Arthur) uttered a low whistle and sauntered away to the window, where he (Arthur) stood for some minutes looking out upon the pleasing prospect of sullen grey clouds, streaming rain, soaking lawn, and dripping leafless trees, and muttering execrations on the weather, and then sat down to breakfast. While taking his (Arthur) coffee he (Arthur) muttered it was `d--d cold.'

`You should not have left it so long,' said I.

He (Arthur) made no answer, and the meal was concluded in silence. It was a relief to both when the letter-bag was brought in. It contained upon examination a newspaper and one or two letters for him (Arthur), and a couple of letters for me, which he (Arthur) tossed across the table without a remark. One was from my brother, the other from Milicent Hargrave, who is now in London with her (Arthur) mother. His (Hargrave), I think, were business letters, and apparently not much to his (Hargrave) mind, for he (Hargrave) crushed them into his (Hargrave) pocket with some muttered expletives that I should have reproved him (Hargrave) for at any other time. The paper he (Hargrave) set before him (Hargrave), and pretended to be deeply absorbed in its contents during the remainder of breakfast, and a considerable time after.

The reading and answering of my letters, and the direction of household concerns, afforded me ample employment for the morning: after lunch I got my drawing, and from dinner till bed-time I read. Meanwhile, poor Arthur was sadly at a loss for something to amuse him (Arthur) or to occupy his (Arthur) time. He (Arthur) wanted to appear as busy and as unconcerned as I did. Had the weather at all permitted, he (Arthur) would doubtless have ordered his (Arthur) horse and set off to some distant region, no matter where, immediately after breakfast, and not returned till night: had there been a lady anywhere within reach, of any age between fifteen and forty-five, he (Arthur) would have sought revenge and found employment in getting up, or trying to get up, a desperate flirtation with her (lady); but being, to my private satisfaction, entirely cut off from both these sources of diversion, his (Arthur) sufferings were truly deplorable. I was not really angry: I felt for him (Arthur) all the time, and longed to be reconciled; but I determined he (Arthur) should make the first advances, or at least show some signs of an humble and contrite spirit first; for, if I began, it would only minister to his (minister) self-conceit, increase his (minister) arrogance, and quite destroy the lesson I wanted to give him (minister).

He (minister) made a long stay in the dining-room after dinner, and, I fear, took an unusual quantity of wine, but not enough to loosen his (minister) tongue: for when he (minister) came in and found me quietly occupied with my book, too busy to lift my head on his (minister) entrance, he (minister) merely murmured an expression of suppressed disapprobation, and, shutting the door with a bang, went and stretched himself at full length on the sofa, and composed himself to sleep. But his (minister) favourite cocker, Dash, that had been lying at my feet, took the liberty of jumping upon him (minister) and beginning to lick his (minister) face. He (minister) struck it off with a smart blow, and the poor dog squeaked and ran cowering back to me. When he (minister) woke up, about half an hour after, he (minister) called it to him (minister) again, but Dash only looked sheepish and wagged the tip of his (Dash) tail. He (Dash) called again more sharply, but Dash only clung the closer to me, and licked my hand, as if imploring protection. Enraged at this, his (Dash) master snatched up a heavy book and hurled it at his (Dash) head. The poor dog set up a piteous outcry, and ran to the door. I let him (Dash) out, and then quietly took up the book.

`Give that book to me,' said Arthur, in no very courteous tone. I gave it to him (Arthur).

`Why did you let the dog out?' he (Arthur) asked; `you knew I wanted him (Arthur).'

`By what token?' I replied; `by your throwing the book at him (Arthur)? but perhaps it was intended for me?'

`No; but I see you've got a taste of it,' said he (Arthur), looking at my hand, that had also been struck, and was rather severely grazed.

I returned to my reading, and he (Arthur) endeavoured to occupy himself in the same manner; but in a little while, after several portentous yawns, he (Arthur) pronounced his (Arthur) book to be `cursed trash,' and threw it on the table. Then followed eight or ten minutes of silence, during the greater part of which, I believe, he (Arthur) was staring at me. At last his (Arthur) patience was tired out.

`What is that book, Helen?' he (Arthur) exclaimed.

I told him (Arthur).

`Is it interesting?'

`Yes, very.'

I went on reading, or pretending to read, at least--I cannot say there was much communication between my eyes and my brain; for, while the former ran over the pages, the latter was earnestly wondering when Arthur would speak next, and what he (Arthur) would say, and what I should answer. But he (Arthur) did not speak again till I rose to make the tea, and then it was only to say he (Arthur) should not take any. He (Arthur) continued lounging on the sofa, and alternately closing his (Arthur) eyes and looking at his (Arthur) watch and at me, till bed-time, when I rose, and took my candle and retired.

`Helen!' cried he (Arthur), the moment I had left the room. I turned back, and stood awaiting his (Arthur) commands.

`What do you want, Arthur?' I said at length.

`Nothing,' replied he (Arthur). `Go!'

I went, but hearing him (Arthur) mutter something as I was closing the door, I turned again. It sounded very like `confounded slut,' but I was quite willing it should be something else.

`Were you speaking, Arthur?' I asked.

`No,' was the answer, and I shut the door and departed. I saw nothing more of him (Arthur) till the following morning at breakfast, when he (Arthur) came down a full hour after the usual time.

`You're very late,' was my morning's salutation.

`You needn't have waited for me,' was his (Arthur); and he (Arthur) walked up to the window again. It was just such weather as yesterday.

`Oh, this confounded rain!' he (Arthur) muttered. But, after studiously regarding it for a minute or two, a bright idea, seemed to strike him (Arthur), for he (Arthur) suddenly exclaimed, `But I know what I'll do!' and then returned and took his (Arthur) seat at the table. The letter-bag was already there, waiting to be opened. He (Arthur) unlocked it and examined the contents, but said nothing about them.

`Is there anything for me?' I asked.

`No.'

He (Arthur) opened the newspaper and began to read.

`You'd better take your coffee,' suggested I; `it will be cold again.'

`You may go,' said he (Arthur), `if you've done; I don't want you.'

I rose and withdrew to the next room, wondering if we were to have another such miserable day as yesterday, and wishing intensely for an end of these mutually inflicted torments. Shortly after I heard him (Arthur) ring the bell and give some orders about his (Arthur) wardrobe that sounded as if he (Arthur) meditated a long journey. He (Arthur) then sent for the coachman, and I heard something about the carriage and the horses, and London, and seven o’clock to-morrow morning, that startled and disturbed me not a little.

`I must not let him (Arthur) go to London, whatever comes of it,' said I to myself; `he (Arthur) will run into all kinds of mischief, and I shall be the cause of it. But the question is, How am I to alter his (Arthur) purpose? Well, I will wait awhile, and see if he (Arthur) mentions it.'

I waited most anxiously, from hour to hour; but not a word was spoken, on that or any other subject, to me. He (Arthur) whistled and talked to his (Arthur) dogs, and wandered from room to room, much the same as on the previous day. At last I began to think I must introduce the subject myself, and was pondering how to bring it about, when John unwittingly came to my relief with the following message from the coachman:

`Please, sir, Richard says one of the horses has got a very bad cold, and he (Richard) thinks, sir, if you could make it convenient to go the day after to-morrow, instead of to-morrow, he (Richard) could physic it to-day, so as--'

`Confound his (Richard) impudence!' interjected the master.

`Please, sir, he (Richard) says it would be a deal better if you could,' persisted John, `for he (John) hopes there'll be a change in the weather shortly, and he (John) says it's not likely, when a horse is so bad with a cold, and physicked and all--'

`Devil take the horse!' cried the gentleman. `Well, tell him (Devil) I'll think about it,' he (Devil) added, after a moment's reflection. He (Devil) cast a searching glance at me, as the servant withdrew, expecting to see some token of deep astonishment and alarm; but, being previously prepared, I preserved an aspect of stoical indifference. His (Devil) countenance fell as he (Devil) met my steady gaze, and he (Devil) turned away in very obvious disappointment, and walked up to the fire-place, where he (Devil) stood in an attitude of undisguised dejection, leaning against the chimney-piece with his (Devil) forehead sunk upon his (Devil) arm.

`Where do you want to go, Arthur?' said I.

`To London,' replied he (Arthur), gravely.

`What for?' I asked.

`Because I cannot be happy here.'

`Why not?'

`Because my wife doesn't love me.'

`She (wife) would love you with all her (wife) heart, if you deserved it.'

`What must I do to deserve it?'

This seemed humble and earnest enough; and I was so much affected, between sorrow and joy, that I was obliged to pause a few seconds before I could steady my voice to reply.

`If she (wife) gives you her (wife) heart,' said I, `you must take it, thankfully, and use it well, and not pull it in pieces, and laugh in her (wife) face, because she (wife) cannot snatch it away.'

He (wife) now turned round, and stood facing me, with his (wife) back to the fire. `Come, then, Helen, are you going to be a good girl?' said he (wife).

This sounded rather too arrogant, and the smile that accompanied it did not please me. I therefore hesitated to reply. Perhaps my former answer had implied too much: he (wife) had heard my voice falter, and might have seen me brush away a tear.

`Are you going to forgive me, Helen?' he (wife) resumed, more humbly.

`Are you penitent?' I replied, stepping up to him (wife) and smiling in his (wife) face.

`Heart-broken!' he (wife) answered, with a rueful countenance, yet with a merry smile just lurking within his (wife) eyes and about the corners of his (wife) mouth; but this could not repulse me, and I flew into his (wife) arms. He (wife) fervently embraced me, and though I shed a torrent of tears, I think I never was happier in my life than at that moment.

`Then you won't go to London, Arthur?' I said, when the first transport of tears and kisses had subsided.

`No, love,--unless you will go with me.'

`I will, gladly,' I answered, `if you think the change will amuse you, and if you will put off the journey till next week.'

He (Arthur) readily consented, but said there was no need of much preparation, as he (Arthur) should not be for staying long, for he (Arthur) did not wish me to be Londonized, and to lose my country freshness and originality by too much intercourse with the ladies of the world. I thought this folly; but I did not wish to contradict him (Arthur) now: I merely said that I was of very domestic habits, as he (Arthur) well knew, and had no particular wish to mingle with the world.

So we are to go to London on Monday, the day after to-morrow. It is now four days since the termination of our quarrel, and I am sure it has done us both good: it has made me like Arthur a great deal better, and made him (Arthur) behave a great deal better to me. He (Arthur) has never once attempted to annoy me since, by the most distant allusion to Lady F--, or any of those disagreeable reminiscences of his (Arthur) former life. I wish I could blot them from my memory, or else get him (Arthur) to regard such matters in the same light as I do. Well! it is something, however, to have made him (Arthur) see that they are not fit subjects for a conjugal jest. He (Arthur) may see further some time. I will put no limits to my hopes; and, in spite of my aunt's forebodings and my own unspoken fears, I trust we shall be happy yet.

CHAPTER XXV

On the eighth of April we went to London, on the eighth of May I returned, in obedience to Arthur's wish; very much against my own, because I left him (Arthur) behind. If he (Arthur) had come with me, I should have been very glad to get home again, for he (Arthur) led me such a round of restless dissipation while there, that, in that short space of time, I was quite tired out. He (Arthur) seemed bent upon displaying me to his (Arthur) friends and acquaintances in particular, and the public in general, on every possible occasion, and to the greatest possible advantage. It was something to feel that he (Arthur) considered me a worthy object of pride; but I paid dear for the gratification: for, in the first place, to please him (Arthur) I had to violate my cherished predilections, my almost rooted principles in favour of a plain, dark, sober style of dress--I must sparkle in costly jewels and deck myself out like a painted butterfly, just as I had, long since, determined I would never do--and this was no trifling sacrifice; in the second place, I was continually straining to satisfy his (Arthur) sanguine expectations and do honour to his (Arthur) choice by my general conduct and deportment, and fearing to disappoint him (Arthur) by some awkward misdemeanour, or some trait of inexperienced ignorance about the customs of society, especially when I acted the part of hostess, which I was not unfrequently called upon to do; and, in the third place, as I intimated before, I was wearied of the throng and bustle, the restless hurry and ceaseless change of a life so alien to all my previous habits. At last, he (Arthur) suddenly discovered that the London air did not agree with me, and I was languishing for my country home, and must immediately return to Grassdale.

I laughingly assured him (Arthur) that the case was not so urgent as he (Arthur) appeared to think it, but I was quite willing to go home if he (Arthur) was. He (Arthur) replied that he (Arthur) should be obliged to remain a week or two longer, as he (Arthur) had business that required his (Arthur) presence.

-LSB-Picture: Blake Hall--Front -LRB-Grassdale Manor-RRB--RSB-

`Then I will stay with you,' said I.

`But I can't do with you, Helen,' was his (Hall) answer: `as long as you stay I shall attend to you and neglect my business.'

`But I won't let you,' I returned; `now that I know you have business to attend to, I shall insist upon your attending to it, and letting me alone; and, to tell the truth, I shall be glad of a little rest. I can take my rides and walks in the Park as usual; and your business cannot occupy all your time: I shall see you at meal-times, and in the evenings at least, and that will be better than being leagues away and never seeing you at all.'

`But, my love, I cannot let you stay. How can I settle my affairs when I know that you are here, neglected--?'

`I shall not feel myself neglected: while you are doing your duty, Arthur, I shall never complain of neglect. If you had told me before, that you had anything to do, it would have been half done before this; and now you must make up for lost time by redoubled exertions. Tell me what it is; and I will be your taskmaster, instead of being a hindrance.'

`No, no,' persisted the impracticable creature; `you must go home, Helen; I must have the satisfaction of knowing that you are safe and well, though far away. Your bright eyes are faded, and that tender, delicate bloom has quite deserted your cheek.'

`That is only with too much gaiety and fatigue.'

`It is not, I tell you; it is the London air: you are pining for the fresh breezes of your country home, and you shall feel them before you are two days older. And remember your situation, dearest Helen; on your health, you know, depends the health, if not the life, of our future hope.'

`Then you really wish to get rid of me?'

`Positively, I do; and I will take you down myself to Grassdale, and then return. I shall not be absent above a week or fortnight at most.'

`But if I must go, I will go alone: if you must stay, it is needless to waste your time in the journey there and back.'

But he (you) did not like the idea of sending me alone.

`Why, what helpless creature do you take me for,' I replied, `that you cannot trust me to go a hundred miles in our own carriage, with our own footman and a maid to attend me? If you come with me I shall assuredly keep you. But tell me, Arthur, what is this tiresome business; and why did you never mention it before?'

`It is only a little business with my lawyer,' said he (lawyer); and he (lawyer) told me something about a piece of property he (lawyer) wanted to sell, in order to pay off a part of the incumbrances on his (lawyer) estate; but either the account was a little confused, or I was rather dull of comprehension, for I could not clearly understand how that should keep him (lawyer) in town a fortnight after me. Still less can I now comprehend how it should keep him (lawyer) a month, for it is nearly that time since I left him (lawyer), and no signs of his (lawyer) return as yet. In every letter he (lawyer) promises to be with me in a few days, and every time deceives me, or deceives himself. His (lawyer) excuses are vague and insufficient. I cannot doubt that he (lawyer) has got among his (lawyer) former companions again. Oh, why did I leave him (lawyer)! I wish--I do intensely wish he (lawyer) would return!

June 29th.--No Arthur yet; and for many days I have been looking and longing in vain for a letter. His (Arthur) letters, when they come, are kind, if fair words and endearing epithets can give them a claim to the title--but very short, and full of trivial excuses and promises that I cannot trust; and yet how anxiously I look forward to them! how eagerly I open and devour one of those little, hastily-scribbled returns for the three or four long letters, hitherto unanswered, he (Arthur) has had from me!

Oh, it is cruel to leave me so long alone! He (Arthur) knows I have no one but Rachel to speak to, for we have no neighbours here, except the Hargraves, whose residence I can dimly descry from these upper windows embosomed among those low, woody hills beyond the Dale. I was glad when I learnt that Milicent was so near us; and her (Rachel) company would be a soothing solace to me now; but she (Rachel) is still in town with her (Rachel) mother; there is no one at the Grove but little Esther and her (Esther) French governess, for Walter is always away. I saw that paragon of manly perfections in London: he (Walter) seemed scarcely to merit the eulogiums of his (Walter) mother and sister, though he (Walter) certainly appeared more conversable and agreeable than Lord Lowborough, more candid and high-minded than Mr. Grimsby, and more polished and gentlemanly than Mr. Hattersley, Arthur's only other friend whom he (Arthur) judged fit to introduce to me.--Oh, Arthur, why won't you come? why won't you write to me at least? You talked about my health: how can you expect me to gather bloom and vigour here, pining in solitude and restless anxiety from day to day?--It would serve you right to come back and find my good looks entirely wasted away. I would beg my uncle and aunt, or my brother, to come and see me, but I do not like to complain of my loneliness to them, and indeed loneliness is the least of my sufferings. But what is he (brother), doing--what is it that keeps him (brother) away? It is this ever-recurring question, and the horrible suggestions it raises, that distract me.

July 3rd.--My last bitter letter has wrung from him (brother) an answer at last, and a rather longer one than usual; but still I don't know what to make of it. He (brother) playfully abuses me for the gall and vinegar of my latest effusion, tells me I can have no conception of the multitudinous engagements that keep him (brother) away, but avers that, in spite of them all, he (brother) will assuredly be with me before the close of next week; though it is impossible for a man so circumstanced as he (man) is to fix the precise day of his (man) return: meantime he (man) exhorts me to the exercise of patience, `that first of woman's virtues,' and desires me to remember the saying, `Absence makes the heart grow fonder,' and comfort myself with the assurance that the longer he (man) stays away the better he (man) shall love me when he (man) returns; and till he (man) does return, he (man) begs I will continue to write to him (man) constantly, for, though he (man) is sometimes too idle and often too busy to answer my letters as they come, he (man) likes to receive them daily; and if I fulfil my threat of punishing his (man) seeming neglect by ceasing to write, he (man) shall be so angry that he (man) will do his (man) utmost to forget me. He (man) adds this piece of intelligence respecting poor Milicent Hargrave:

`Your little friend Milicent is likely, before long, to follow your example, and take upon her (man) the yoke of matrimony in conjunction with a friend of mine. Hattersley, you know, has not yet fulfilled his (Hattersley) direful threat of throwing his (Hattersley) precious person away on the first old maid that chose to evince a tenderness for him (Hattersley); but he (Hattersley) still preserves a resolute determination to see himself a married man before the year is out.

CHAPTER XXVI

Sept. 23rd.--Our guests arrived about three weeks ago. Lord and Lady Lowborough have now been married above eight months; and I will do the lady the credit to say that her (lady) husband is quite an altered man; his (husband) looks, his (husband) spirits, and his (husband) temper, are all perceptibly changed for the better since I last saw him (husband). I have never reproached the former but once, and that was for laughing at Lord Lowborough's depressed and anxious countenance one evening, when they had both been particularly provoking; and then, indeed, I said a good deal on the subject, and rebuked him (Lowborough) sternly enough; but he (Lowborough) only laughed, and said,--`You can feel for him (Lowborough), Helen, can't you?'

He (Lowborough) either has not the sense or the power to follow my example, though he (Lowborough) does try to conceal his (Lowborough) uneasiness as well as he (Lowborough) can; but still, it will appear in his (Lowborough) face, and his (Lowborough) ill-humour will peep out at intervals, though not in the expression of open resentment--they never go far enough for that. 28th.--Yesterday, we all went to the Grove, Mr. Hargrave's much-neglected home. His (Hargrave) mother frequently asks us over, that she (mother) may have the pleasure of her (mother) dear Walter's company; and this time she (mother) had invited us to a dinner-party, and got together as many of the country gentry as were within reach to meet us. The entertainment was very well got up; but I could not help thinking about the cost of it all the time. I don't like Mrs. Hargrave; she (Hargrave) is a hard, pretentious, worldly-minded woman. She (Hargrave) has money enough to live very comfortably, if she (Hargrave) only knew how to use it judiciously, and had taught her (Hargrave) son to do the same; but she (Hargrave) is ever straining to keep up appearances, with that despicable pride that shuns the semblance of poverty as of a shameful crime. She (Hargrave) grinds her (Hargrave) dependents, pinches her (Hargrave) servants, and deprives even her (Hargrave) daughters and herself of the real comforts of life, because she (Hargrave) will not consent to yield the palm in outward show to those who have three times her (Hargrave) wealth; and, above all, because she (Hargrave) is determined her (Hargrave) cherished son shall be enabled to `hold up his (son) head with the highest gentlemen in the land.' This same son, I imagine, is a man of expensive habits, no reckless spendthrift and no abandoned sensualist, but one who likes to have `everything handsome about him (son),' and to go to a certain length in youthful indulgences, not so much to gratify his (son) own tastes as to maintain his (son) reputation as a man of fashion in the world, and a respectable fellow among his (fellow) own lawless companions; while he (fellow) is too selfish to consider how many comforts might be obtained for his (fellow) fond mother and sisters with the money he (fellow) thus wastes upon himself: as long as they can contrive to make a respectable appearance once a year, when they come to town, he (fellow) gives himself little concern about their private stintings and struggles at home. This is a harsh judgment to form of `dear, noble-minded, generous-hearted Walter,' but I fear it is too just.

Mrs. Hargrave's anxiety to make good matches for her (Hargrave) daughters is partly the cause, and partly the result, of these errors: by making a figure in the world, and showing them off to advantage, she (Hargrave) hopes to obtain better chances for them; and by thus living beyond her (Hargrave) legitimate means, and lavishing so much on their brother, she (Hargrave) renders them portionless, and makes them burdens on her (Hargrave) hands. Poor Milicent, I fear, has already fallen a sacrifice to the manoeuvrings of this mistaken mother, who congratulates herself on having so satisfactorily discharged her (mother) maternal duty, and hopes to do as well for Esther. But Esther is a child as yet, a little merry romp of fourteen: as honest-hearted, and as guileless and simple as her (Esther) sister, but with a fearless spirit of her (Esther) own, that I fancy her (Esther) mother will find some difficulty in bending to her (Esther) purposes.

CHAPTER XXVII

My heart felt ready to burst; but I resolutely swallowed back my emotion, and answered calmly,

`You think not?'

`No,' replied he (you), boldly. `After all, what have I done? It's nothing--except as you choose to make it a subject of accusation and distress.'

`What would Lord Lowborough, your friend, think, if he (Lowborough) knew all? or what would you yourself think, if he (Lowborough) or any other had acted the same part to me, throughout, as you have to Annabella?'

`I would blow his (Annabella) brains out.'

`Well, then, Arthur, how can you call it nothing--an offence for which you would think yourself justified in blowing another man's brains out? Is it nothing to trifle with your friend's feelings and mine--to endeavour to steal a woman's affections from her (woman) husband--what he (husband) values more than his (husband) gold, and therefore what it is more dishonest to take? Are the marriage vows a jest; and is it nothing to make it your sport to break them, and to tempt another to do the same? Can I love a man that does such things, and coolly maintains it is nothing?'

`You are breaking your marriage vows yourself,' said he (man), indignantly rising and pacing to and fro. `You promised to honour and obey me, and now you attempt to hector over me, and threaten and accuse me, and call me worse than a highwayman. If it were not for your situation, Helen, I would not submit to it so tamely. I won't be dictated to by a woman, though she (woman) be my wife.'

`What will you do then? Will you go on till I hate you, and then accuse me of breaking my vows?'

He (you) was silent a moment, and then replied: `You never will hate me.' Returning and resuming his (you) former position at my feet, he (you) repeated more vehemently--`You cannot hate me as long as I love you.'

`But how can I believe that you love me, if you continue to act in this way? Just imagine yourself in my place: would you think I loved you, if I did so? Would you believe my protestations, and honour and trust me under such circumstances?'

`The cases are different,' he (you) replied. `It is a woman's nature to be constant--to love one and one only, blindly, tenderly, and for ever--bless them, dear creatures! and you above them all; but you must have some commiseration for us, Helen; you must give us a little more licence, for, as Shakespeare has it--

However we do praise ourselves, Our fancies are more giddy and unfirm, More longing, wavering, sooner lost and won Than women's are.'

`Do you mean by that, that your fancies are lost to me, and won by Lady Lowborough?'

`No! heaven is my witness that I think her (Lowborough) mere dust and ashes in comparison with you, and shall continue to think so, unless you drive me from you by too much severity. She (Lowborough) is a daughter of earth; you are an angel of heaven; only be not too austere in your divinity, and remember that I am a poor, fallible mortal. Come now, Helen; won't you forgive me?' he (angel) said, gently taking my hand, and looking up with an innocent smile.

`If I do, you will repeat the offence.'

`I swear by--'

`Don't swear; I'll believe your word as well as your oath. I wish I could have confidence in either.'

`Try me, then, Helen: only trust and pardon me this once, and you shall see! Come, I am in hell's torments till you speak the word.'

I did not speak it, but I put my hand on his (you) shoulder and kissed his (you) forehead, and then burst into tears. He (you) embraced me tenderly; and we have been good friends ever since. He (you) has been decently temperate at table, and well-conducted towards Lady Lowborough. I think I will. She (lady) will take it as a kind attention, and, though I have little relish for her (lady) society, she (lady) will be truly welcome as a third to stand between Lady Lowborough and me.

The first time the latter and I were alone together, after that unhappy evening, was an hour or two after breakfast on the following day, when the gentlemen were gone out, after the usual time spent in the writing of letters, the reading of newspapers, and desultory conversation. We sat silent for two or three minutes. She (Lowborough) was the first to speak; and, smiling with the coolest assurance, she (Lowborough) began,--

`Your husband was merry last night, Helen: is he (husband) often so?'

My blood boiled in my face; but it was better she (Helen) should seem to attribute his (husband) conduct to this than to anything else.

`No,' replied I, `and never will be so again, I trust.'

`You gave him (husband) a curtain lecture, did you?'

`No! but I told him (husband) I disliked such conduct, and he (husband) promised me not to repeat it.'

`I thought he (husband) looked rather subdued this morning,' she (Helen) continued; `and you, Helen? you've been weeping, I see--that's our grand resource, you know. But doesn't it make your eyes smart? and do you always find it to answer?'

`Well, I don't know: I never had occasion to try it; but I think if Lowborough were to commit such improprieties, I'd make him (husband) cry. I don't wonder at your being angry, for I'm sure I'd give my husband a lesson he (husband) would not soon forget for a lighter offence than that. But then he (husband) never will do anything of the kind; for I keep him (husband) in too good order for that.'

`Are you sure you don't arrogate too much of the credit to yourself. Lord Lowborough was quite as remarkable for his (Lowborough) abstemiousness for some time before you married him (Lowborough), as he (Lowborough) is now, I have heard.'

`Oh, about the wine you mean--yes, he (Lowborough)'s safe enough for that. And as to looking askance to another woman, he (Lowborough)'s safe enough for that too, while I live, for he (Lowborough) worships the very ground I tread on.'

`Indeed! and are you sure you deserve it?'

`Why, as to that, I can't say: you know we're all fallible creatures, Helen; we none of us deserve to be worshipped. But are you sure your darling Huntingdon deserves all the love you give to him (Lowborough)?'

I knew not what to answer to this. I was burning with anger; but I suppressed all outward manifestations of it, and only bit my lip and pretended to arrange my work.

`At any rate,' resumed she (Helen), pursuing her (Helen) advantage, `you can console yourself with the assurance that you are worthy of all the love he (lip) gives to you.'

`You flatter me,' said I; `but, at least, I can try to be worthy of it.' And then I turned the conversation.

CHAPTER XXVIII

December 25th.--Last Christmas I was a bride, with a heart overflowing with present bliss, and full of ardent hopes for the future, though not unmingled with foreboding fears. Now I am a wife: my bliss is sobered, but not destroyed; my hopes diminished, but not departed; my fears increased, but not yet thoroughly confirmed; and, thank heaven, I am a mother too. God has sent me a soul to educate for heaven, and give me a new and calmer bliss, and stronger hopes to comfort me.

Dec. 25th, 1823.--Another year is gone. My little Arthur lives and thrives. He (Arthur) is healthy, but not robust, full of gentle playfulness and vivacity, already affectionate, and susceptible of passions and emotions it will be long ere he (Arthur) can find words to express. He (Arthur) has won his (Arthur) father's heart at last; and now my constant terror is, lest he (Arthur) should be ruined by that father's thoughtless indulgence. But I must beware of my own weakness too, for I never knew till now how strong are a parent's temptations to spoil an only child.

I have need of consolation in my son, for -LRB-to this silent paper I may confess it-RRB- I have but little in my husband. I love him (husband) still; and he (husband) loves me, in his (husband) own way--but oh, how different from the love I could have given, and once had hoped to receive! How little real sympathy there exists between us; how many of my thoughts and feelings are gloomily cloistered within my own mind; how much of my higher and better self is indeed unmarried--doomed either to harden and sour in the sunless shade of solitude, or to quite degenerate and fall away for lack of nutriment in this unwholesome soil! But, I repeat, I have no right to complain; only let me state the truth--some of the truth, at least,--and see hereafter if any darker truths will blot these pages. We have now been full two years united; the `romance' of our attachment must be worn away. Surely I have now got down to the lowest gradation in Arthur's affection, and discovered all the evils of his (Arthur) nature: if there be any further change, it must be for the better, as we become still more accustomed to each other; surely we shall find no lower depth than this. And, if so, I can bear it well--as well, at least, as I have borne it hitherto.

Arthur is not what is commonly called a bad man: he (Arthur) has many good qualities; but he (Arthur) is a man without self-restraint or lofty aspirations, a lover of pleasure, given up to animal enjoyments: he (Arthur) is not a bad husband, but his (Arthur) notions of matrimonial duties and comforts are not my notions. Judging from appearances, his (Arthur) idea of a wife is a thing to love one devotedly, and to stay at home to wait upon her (wife) husband, and amuse him (husband) and minister to his (husband) comfort in every possible way, while he (husband) chooses to stay with her (wife); and, when he (husband) is absent, to attend to his (husband) interests, domestic or otherwise, and patiently wait his (husband) return, no matter how he (husband) may be occupied in the meantime.

Early in spring he (husband) announced his (husband) intention of going to London: his (husband) affairs there demanded his (husband) attendance, he (husband) said, and he (husband) could refuse it no longer. He (husband) expressed his (husband) regret at having to leave me, but hoped I would amuse myself with the baby till he (husband) returned.

`But why leave me?' I said. `I can go with you: I can be ready at any time.'

`You would not take that child to town?'

`Yes; why not?'

The thing was absurd: the air of the town would be certain to disagree with him (husband), and with me as a nurse; the late hours and London habits would not suit me under such circumstances; and altogether he (husband) assured me that it would be excessively troublesome, injurious, and unsafe. I over-ruled his (husband) objections as well as I could, for I trembled at the thoughts of his (husband) going alone, and would sacrifice almost anything for myself, much even for my child, to prevent it; but at length he (husband) told me, plainly, and somewhat testily, that he (husband) could not do with me: he (husband) was worn out with the baby's restless nights, and must have some repose. I proposed separate apartments; but it would not do.

`The truth is, Arthur,' I said at last, `you are weary of my company, and determined not to have me with you. You might as well have said so at once.'

He (Arthur) denied it; but I immediately left the room, and flew to the nursery, to hide my feelings, if I could not soothe them, there.

I was too much hurt to express any further dissatisfaction with his (Arthur) plans, or at all to refer to the subject again, except for the necessary arrangements concerning his (Arthur) departure and the conduct of affairs during his (Arthur) absence, till the day before he (Arthur) went, when I earnestly exhorted him (Arthur) to take care of himself and keep out of the way of temptation. He (Arthur) laughed at my anxiety, but assured me there was no cause for it, and promised to attend to my advice.

`I suppose it is no use asking you to fix a day for your return?' said I.

`Why, no; I hardly can, under the circumstances; but be assured, love, I shall not be long away.'

`I don't wish to keep you a prisoner at home,' I replied; `I should not grumble at your staying whole months away--if you can be happy so long without me--provided I knew you were safe; but I don't like the idea of your being there among your friends, as you call them.'

`Pooh, pooh, you silly girl! Do you think I can't take care of myself?'

`You didn't last time. But THIS time, Arthur,' I added, earnestly, `show me that you can, and teach me that I need not fear to trust you!'

He (Arthur) promised fair, but in such a manner as we seek to soothe a child. And did he (Arthur) keep his (Arthur) promise? No; and henceforth I can never trust his (Arthur) word. Bitter, bitter confession! Tears blind me while I write. It was early in March that he (Arthur) went, and he (Arthur) did not return till July. This time he (Arthur) did not trouble himself to make excuses as before, and his (Arthur) letters were less frequent, and shorter and less affectionate, especially after the first few weeks: they came slower and slower, and more terse and careless every time. But still, when I omitted writing, he (Arthur) complained of my neglect. When I wrote sternly and coldly, as I confess I frequently did at the last, he (Arthur) blamed my harshness, and said it was enough to scare him (Arthur) from his (Arthur) home: when I tried mild persuasion, he (Arthur) was a little more gentle in his (Arthur) replies, and promised to return; but I had learnt, at last, to disregard his (Arthur) promises.

CHAPTER XXIX

Those were four miserable months, alternating between intense anxiety, despair, and indignation, pity for him (Arthur) and pity for myself. And yet, through all, I was not wholly comfortless: I had my darling, sinless, inoffensive little one to console me; but even this consolation was embittered by the constantly-recurring thought, `How shall I teach him (Arthur) hereafter to respect his (Arthur) father, and yet to avoid his (Arthur) example?'

But I remembered that I had brought all these afflictions, in a manner wilfully, upon myself; and I determined to bear them without a murmur. At the same time I resolved not to give myself up to misery for the transgressions of another, and endeavoured to divert myself as much as I could; and besides the companionship of my child, and my dear, faithful Rachel, who evidently guessed my sorrows and felt for them, though she (Rachel) was too discreet to allude to them, I had my books and pencil, my domestic affairs, and the welfare and comfort of Arthur's poor tenants and labourers to attend to: and I sometimes sought and obtained amusement in the company of my young friend Esther Hargrave: occasionally I rode over to see her (Hargrave), and once or twice I had her (Hargrave) to spend the day with me at the Manor. Mrs. Hargrave did not visit London that season: having no daughter to marry, she (Hargrave) thought it as well to stay at home and economise; and, for a wonder, Walter came down to join her (Hargrave) in the beginning of June, and stayed till near the close of August.

The first time I saw him (Walter) was on a sweet, warm evening, when I was sauntering in the park with little Arthur and Rachel, who is head-nurse and lady's-maid in one--for, with my secluded life and tolerably active habits, I require but little attendance, and as she (maid) had nursed me and coveted to nurse my child, and was moreover so very trustworthy, I preferred committing the important charge to her (maid), with a young nursery-maid under her (maid) directions, to engaging any one else: besides, it saves money; and since I have made acquaintance with Arthur's affairs, I have learnt to regard that as no trifling recommendation; for, by my own desire, nearly the whole of the income of my fortune is devoted, for years to come, to the paying off of his (Arthur) debts, and the money he (Arthur) contrives to squander away in London is incomprehensible. I was standing with Rachel beside the water, amusing the laughing baby in her (Rachel) arms with a twig of willow laden with golden catkins, when, greatly to my surprise, he (Hargrave) entered the park, mounted on his (Hargrave) costly black hunter, and crossed over the grass to meet me. He (Hargrave) saluted me with a very fine compliment, delicately worded, and modestly delivered withal, which he (Hargrave) had doubtless concocted as he (Hargrave) rode along. He (Hargrave) told me he (Hargrave) had brought a message from his (Hargrave) mother, who, as he (Hargrave) was riding that way, had desired him (Hargrave) to call at the Manor and beg the pleasure of my company to a friendly family dinner to-morrow.

`There is no one to meet but ourselves,' said he (Hargrave); `but Esther is very anxious to see you; and my mother fears you will feel solitary in this great house so much alone, and wishes she (mother) could persuade you to give her (mother) the pleasure of your company more frequently, and make yourself at home in our more humble dwelling, till Mr. Huntingdon's return shall render this a little more conducive to your comfort.'

`She (mother) is very kind,' I answered, `but I am not alone, you see;--and those whose time is fully occupied seldom complain of solitude.'

`Will you not come to-morrow, then? She (mother) will be sadly disappointed if you refuse.'

I did not relish being thus compassionated for my loneliness; but, however, I promised to come.

`What a sweet evening this is!' observed he (Huntingdon), looking round upon the sunny park, with its imposing swell and slope, its placid water, and majestic clumps of trees. `And what a paradise you live in!'

`It is a lovely evening,' answered I; and I sighed to think how little I had felt its loveliness, and how little of a paradise sweet Grassdale was to me--how still less to the voluntary exile from its scenes. Whether Mr. Hargrave divined my thoughts, I cannot tell, but, with a half-hesitating, sympathising seriousness of tone and manner, he (Hargrave) asked if I had lately heard from Mr. Huntingdon.

`Not lately,' I replied.

`I thought not,' he (Huntingdon) muttered, as if to himself, looking thoughtfully on the ground.

`Only yesterday.'

`And did you see him (Huntingdon) there?'

`Yes--I saw him (Huntingdon).'

He (man) here looked up and pointed the sentence with a serious bow to me. I suppose my face was crimson.

`If you knew more of me, you would not think it, or if you did you would not say it, and expect me to be flattered by the compliment.'

I stepped backward as I spoke. CHAPTER XXX

On the following morning I received a few lines from him (Arthur) myself, confirming Hargrave's intimations respecting his (Hargrave) approaching return. And he (Hargrave) did come next week, but in a condition of body and mind even worse than before. Next morning he (Hargrave) was weary still: I would wait a little longer. `It is the same cook as we had before you went, Arthur,' said I. `You were generally pretty well satisfied with her (you) then.'

`I think it is you that are changed, not she (you),' said I, but with the utmost gentleness, for I did not wish to irritate him (Arthur).

`It may be so,' he (Arthur) replied carelessly, as he (Arthur) seized a tumbler of wine and water, adding, when he (Arthur) had tossed it off, `for I have an infernal fire in my veins, that all the waters of the ocean cannot quench!'

`What kindled it?' I was about to ask, but at that moment the butler entered and began to take away the things.

`Be quick, Benson; do have done with that infernal clatter!' cried his (Benson) master. `And don't bring the cheese, unless you want to make me sick outright!'

Benson, in some surprise, removed the cheese, and did his (Benson) best to effect a quiet and speedy clearance of the rest; but, unfortunately, there was a rumple in the carpet, caused by the hasty pushing back of his (Benson) master's chair, at which he (Benson) tripped and stumbled, causing a rather alarming concussion with the trayful of crockery in his (Benson) hands, but no positive damage, save the fall and breaking of a sauce tureen; but, to my unspeakable shame and dismay, Arthur turned furiously around upon him (Arthur), and swore at him (Arthur) with savage coarseness. `He (man) couldn't help it, Arthur,' said I; `the carpet caught his (Arthur) foot, and there's no great harm done. Never mind the pieces now, Benson; you can clear them away afterwards.'

Glad to be released, Benson expeditiously set out the dessert and withdrew.

`What could you mean, Helen, by taking the servant's part against me,' said Arthur, as soon as the door was closed, `when you knew I was distracted?'

`I did not know you were distracted, Arthur: and the poor man was quite frightened and hurt at your sudden explosion.'

He (servant) leant his (servant) head on his (servant) hand, and sighed. I went to him (servant) and put my hand on his (servant) forehead. It was burning indeed.

Thenceforth I restrained my tears and passions as much as I could. September 30th.--Our guests have been here a week or two; but I have had no leisure to pass any comments upon them till now. I cannot get over my dislike to Lady Lowborough. It is not founded on mere personal pique; it is the woman herself that I dislike, because I so thoroughly disapprove of her (woman). I always avoid her (woman) company as much as I can without violating the laws of hospitality; but when we do speak or converse together, it is with the utmost civility, even apparent cordiality on her (woman) part; but preserve me from such cordiality! It is like handling brier-roses and may-blossoms, bright enough to the eye, and outwardly soft to the touch, but you know there are thorns beneath, and every now and then you feel them too; and perhaps resent the injury by crushing them in till you have destroyed their power, though somewhat to the detriment of your own fingers.

`I shall complain to no one. Hitherto I have struggled hard to hide your vices from every eye, and invest you with virtues you never possessed; but now you must look to yourself.'

`Yes, you were always for

``bearing.'' (I)
But if I was you I wouldn't bear it; I'd give way to it, and cry right hard! and I'd talk too, I just would--I'd let him (man) know what it was to--'

Notwithstanding this resolution, I found my bed so intolerable that, before two o’clock, I rose, and lighting my candle by the rushlight that was still burning, I got my desk and sat down in my dressing-gown to recount the events of the past evening. It was better to be so occupied than to be lying in bed torturing my brain with recollections of the far past and anticipations of the dreadful future. I have found relief in describing the very circumstances that have destroyed my peace, as well as the little trivial details attendant upon their discovery. No sleep I could have got this night would have done so much towards composing my mind, and preparing me to meet the trials of the day. I fancy so, at least; and yet, when I cease writing, I find my head aches terribly; and when I look into the glass, I am startled at my haggard, worn appearance.

Rachel has been to dress me, and says I have had a sad night of it, she (Rachel) can see. Milicent has just looked in to ask me how I was. I told her (Rachel) I was better, but to excuse my appearance admitted I had had a restless night. I wish this day were over! I shudder at the thoughts of going down to breakfast. How shall I encounter them all? Yet let me remember it is not I that am guilty: I have no cause to fear; and if they scorn me as a victim of their guilt, I can pity their folly and despise their scorn.

CHAPTER XXXIV

Evening.--Breakfast passed well over: I was calm and cool throughout. I answered composedly all inquiries respecting my health; and whatever was unusual in my look or manner was generally attributed to the trifling indisposition that had occasioned my early retirement last night. CHAPTER XXXV

`How much allegiance do you owe to that man?' he (man) asked below his (man) breath, as he (man) stood beside me at the window, affecting to be making observations on the weather.

He (man) followed, and would have entered into some kind of conversation with me, but the other guests were now beginning to assemble, and I took no more notice of him (man), except to give him (man) his (man) coffee.

`Yes,' said I, without moving, or raising my eyes from my book, `free to do anything but offend God and my conscience.'

There was a momentary pause.

`Very right,' said he (God), `provided your conscience be not too morbidly tender, and your ideas of God not too erroneously severe; but can you suppose it would offend that benevolent Being to make the happiness of one who would die for yours?--to raise a devoted heart from purgatorial torments to a state of heavenly bliss, when you could do it without the slightest injury to yourself or any other?'

This was spoken in a low, earnest, melting tone, as he (God) bent over me. I now raised my head; and steadily confronting his (God) gaze, I answered calmly, `Mr. Hargrave, do you mean to insult me?'

He (Hargrave) was not prepared for this. He (Hargrave) paused a moment to recover the shock; then, drawing himself up and removing his (Hargrave) hand from my chair, he (Hargrave) answered, with proud sadness,--`That was not my intention.'

I just glanced towards the door, with a slight movement of the head, and then returned to my book. He (Hargrave) immediately withdrew. This was better than if I had answered with more words, and in the passionate spirit to which my first impulse would have prompted. What a good thing it is to be able to command one's temper! I must labour to cultivate this inestimable quality: God only knows how often I shall need it in this rough, dark road that lies before me.

In the course of the morning I drove over to the Grove with the two ladies, to give Milicent an opportunity for bidding farewell to her (Hargrave) mother and sister. With her (Lowborough) usual impudence, my companion then made some attempts to get up a conversation; but the monosyllables `yes,' or `no' or `humph,' were the utmost her (Lowborough) several remarks could elicit from me. At last, on her (Lowborough) asking my opinion upon some immaterial point of discussion, I answered,--`Why do you wish to talk to me, Lady Lowborough? You must know what I think of you.'

`Well, if you will be so bitter against me,' replied she (Lowborough), `I can't help it; but I'm not going to sulk for anybody.' Our short drive was now at an end. But I had not done with her (Lowborough) impudence yet: after dinner, I retired to the drawing-room, as usual, and she (Lowborough) accompanied me, but I had the two children with me, and I gave them my whole attention, and determined to keep them till the gentlemen came, or till Milicent arrived with her (Lowborough) mother. `Well,' resumed she (Huntingdon), `have you not observed the salutary change in Mr. Huntingdon? Don't you see what a sober, temperate man he (man) is become? You saw with regret the sad habits he (man) was contracting, I know: and I know you did your utmost to deliver him (man) from them, but without success, until I came to your assistance. I told him (man) in few words that I could not bear to see him (man) degrade himself so, and that I should cease to--no matter what I told him (man), but you see the reformation I have wrought; and you ought to thank me for it.'

I rose and rang for the nurse.

`But I desire no thanks,' she (nurse) continued; `all the return I ask is, that you will take care of him (man) when I am gone, and not, by harshness and neglect, drive him (man) back to his (man) old courses.'

I was almost sick with passion, but Rachel was now at the door. I pointed to the children, for I could not trust myself to speak: she (Rachel) took them away, and I followed.

`Will you, Helen?' continued the speaker.

I gave her (Helen) a look that blighted the malicious smile on her (Helen) face, or checked it, at least for a moment, and departed. In the ante-room I met Mr. Hargrave. `Mrs. Huntingdon,' said he (Milicent) as I passed, `will you allow me one word?'

`What is it then? be quick, if you please.'

`I offended you this morning; and I cannot live under your displeasure.'

`Then go, and sin no more,' replied I, turning away.

`No, no!' said he (Milicent), hastily, setting himself before me. `Pardon me, but I must have your forgiveness. I leave you to-morrow, and I may not have an opportunity of speaking to you again. I was wrong to forget myself and you, as I did; but let me implore you to forget and forgive my rash presumption, and think of me as if those words had never been spoken; for, believe me, I regret them deeply, and the loss of your esteem is too severe a penalty: I cannot bear it.'

`Forgetfulness is not to be purchased with a wish; and I cannot bestow my esteem on all who desire it, unless they deserve it too.'

`I shall think my life well spent in labouring to deserve it, if you will but pardon this offence--will you?'

`Yes.'

`Yes! but that is coldly spoken. Give me your hand and I'll believe you. You won't? Then, Mrs. Huntingdon, you do not forgive me!'

`Yes; here it is, and my forgiveness with it: only, _sin no more_.'

He (you) pressed my cold hand with sentimental fervour, but said nothing, and stood aside to let me pass into the room, where all the company were now assembled. Mr. Grimsby was seated near the door: on seeing me enter, almost immediately followed by Hargrave, he (Hargrave) leered at me with a glance of intolerable significance, as I passed. I looked him (Hargrave) in the face, till he (Hargrave) sullenly turned away, if not ashamed, at least confounded for the moment. Thank heaven, they are all going to-morrow.

CHAPTER XXXVI

December 20th, 1824.--This is the third anniversary of our felicitous union. It is now two months since our guests left us to the enjoyment of each other's society; and I have had nine weeks' experience of this new phase of conjugal life--two persons living together, as master and mistress of the house, and father and mother of a winsome, merry little child, with the mutual understanding that there is no love, friendship, or sympathy between them. As far as in me lies, I endeavour to live peaceably with him (father): I treat him (father) with unimpeachable civility, give up my convenience to his (father), wherever it may reasonably be done, and consult him (father) in a business-like way on household affairs, deferring to his (father) pleasure and judgment, even when I know the latter to be inferior to my own.

Again I proposed a separation, but it would not do: he (father) was not going to be the talk of all the old gossips in the neighbourhood: he (father) would not have it said that he (father) was such a brute his (father) wife could not live with him (father). `I must contrive to bear with you, you mean,' said I; `for so long as I discharge my functions of steward and house-keeper, so conscientiously and well, without pay and without thanks, you cannot afford to part with me. I believe he (steward) was much disappointed that I did not feel his (steward) offensive sayings more acutely, for when he (steward) had said anything particularly well calculated to hurt my feelings, he (steward) would stare me searchingly in the face, and then grumble against my `marble heart' or my `brutal insensibility.' When he (steward) is under the exciting influence of these excesses, he (steward) sometimes fires up and attempts to play the brute; and then I take little pains to suppress my scorn and disgust. When he (steward) is under the depressing influence of the after-consequences, he (steward) bemoans his (steward) sufferings and his (steward) errors, and charges them both upon me; he (steward) knows such indulgence injures his (steward) health, and does him (steward) more harm than good; but he (steward) says I drive him (steward) to it by my unnatural, unwomanly conduct; it will be the ruin of him (steward) in the end, but it is all my fault; and then I am roused to defend myself, sometimes with bitter recrimination. Would I not labour still to deliver him (steward) from it if I could? but could I do so by fawning upon him (steward) and caressing him (steward) when I know that he (steward) scorns me? Is it my fault that I have lost my influence with him (steward), or that he (steward) has forfeited every claim to my regard? No, never, never, never! he (steward) may drink himself dead, but it is NOT my fault!

Yet I do my part to save him (steward) still: I give him (steward) to understand that drinking makes his (steward) eyes dull, and his (steward) face red and bloated; and that it tends to render him (steward) imbecile in body and mind; and if Annabella were to see him (Annabella) as often as I do, she (Lowborough) would speedily be disenchanted; and that she (Lowborough) certainly will withdraw her (Lowborough) favour from him (Annabella), if he (Annabella) continues such courses. At present I am enjoying a temporary relief from his (Annabella) presence: he (Annabella) is gone with Hargrave to join a distant hunt, and will probably not be back before to-morrow evening. How differently I used to feel his (Annabella) absence!

Mr. Hargrave is still at the Grove. He (Hargrave) and Arthur frequently meet to pursue their rural sports together: he (Hargrave) often calls upon us here, and Arthur not unfrequently rides over to him (Arthur). I do not think either of these soi-disant friends is overflowing with love for the other; but such intercourse serves to get the time on, and I am very willing it should continue, as it saves me some hours of discomfort in Arthur's society, and gives him (Arthur) some better employment than the sottish indulgence of his (Arthur) sensual appetites. February 10th.--It is a hard, embittering thing to have one's kind feelings and good intentions cast back in one's teeth. I was beginning to relent towards my wretched partner; to pity his (Hargrave) forlorn, comfortless condition, unalleviated as it is by the consolations of intellectual resources and the answer of a good conscience towards God; and to think I ought to sacrifice my pride, and renew my efforts once again to make his (God) home agreeable and lead him (God) back to the path of virtue; not by false professions of love, and not by pretended remorse, but by mitigating my habitual coldness of manner, and commuting my frigid civility into kindness wherever an opportunity occurred; and not only was I beginning to think so, but I had already begun to act upon the thought--and what was the result? No answering spark of kindness, no awakening penitence, but an unappeasable ill-humour, and a spirit of tyrannous exaction that increased with indulgence, and a lurking gleam of self-complacent triumph at every detection of relenting softness in my manner, that congealed me to marble again as often as it recurred; and this morning he (my) finished the business:--I think the petrifaction is so completely effected at last that nothing can melt me again. Among his (my) letters was one which he (my) perused with symptoms of unusual gratification, and then threw it across the table to me, with the admonition,--

`There! read that, and take a lesson by it!'

It was in the free, dashing hand of Lady Lowborough. I glanced at the first page; it seemed full of extravagant protestations of affection; impetuous longings for a speedy reunion--and impious defiance of God's mandates, and railings against His (God) providence for having cast their lot asunder, and doomed them both to the hateful bondage of alliance with those they could not love. He (God) gave a slight titter on seeing me change colour. I folded up the letter, rose, and returned it to him (God), with no remark, but--

`Thank you, I will take a lesson by it!'

Hearing his (Arthur) cries, the father came to the room. I instantly turned away, lest he (Arthur) should see and misconstrue my emotion. He (Arthur) swore at me, and took the now pacified child away.

It is hard that my little darling should love him (Arthur) more than me; and that, when the well-being and culture of my son is all I have to live for, I should see my influence destroyed by one whose selfish affection is more injurious than the coldest indifference or the harshest tyranny could be. If I, for his (son) good, deny him (son) some trifling indulgence, he (son) goes to his (son) father, and the latter, in spite of his (son) selfish indolence, will even give himself some trouble to meet the child's desires: if I attempt to curb his (son) will, or look gravely on him (son) for some act of childish disobedience, he (son) knows his (son) other parent will smile and take his (son) part against me. But it is wrong to despair; I will remember the counsel of the inspired writer to him (writer) `that feareth the Lord and obeyeth the voice of his (Lord) servant, that sitteth in darkness and hath no light; let him (Lord) trust in the name of the Lord, and stay upon his (Lord) God!'

CHAPTER XXXVII

December 20th, 1825.--Another year is past; and I am weary of this life. And yet I cannot wish to leave it: whatever afflictions assail me here, I cannot wish to go and leave my darling in this dark and wicked world alone, without a friend to guide him (friend) through its weary mazes, to warn him (friend) of its thousand snares, and guard him (guard) from the perils that beset him (guard) on every hand. I am not well fitted to be his (guard) only companion, I know; but there is no other to supply my place. I am too grave to minister to his (minister) amusements and enter into his (minister) infantile sports as a nurse or a mother ought to do, and often his (minister) bursts of gleeful merriment trouble and alarm me; I see in them his (minister) father's spirit and temperament, and I tremble for the consequences; and too often damp the innocent mirth I ought to share. `Is he (Lowborough) not your friend?' said I, turning my eyes from the fire to his (Lowborough) face, with perhaps a slight touch of those feelings he (Lowborough) assigned to another.

`Revenge! No--what good would that do?--it would make him (man) no better, and me no happier.'

`No, I am the ordinary mortal, I maintain,' replied Mr. Hargrave. `I will not allow myself to be worse than my fellows; but you, Madam--I equally maintain there is nobody like you. But are you happy?' he (Hargrave) asked in a serious tone.

`As happy as some others, I suppose.'

`Are you as happy as you desire to be?'

`No one is so blest as that comes to on this side eternity.'

`One thing I know,' returned he (Hargrave), with a deep sad sigh; `you are immeasurably happier than I am.'

But one mild, sunshiny day, early in November, I had ventured forth alone to visit the village school and a few of the poor tenants, and on my return I was alarmed at the clatter of a horse's feet behind me, approaching at a rapid, steady trot. `In the first place, I don't believe you,' answered I; `in the second, if you will be such a fool, I can't hinder it.'

`If you affect,' replied he (fool), earnestly, `to regard as folly the best, the strongest, the most godlike impulses of our nature, I don't believe you.
