`I own I cannot; but we know not that it will be so;--and I do know that to regret the exchange of earthly pleasures for the joys of heaven, is as if the grovelling caterpillar should lament that it must one day quit the nibbled leaf to soar aloft and flutter through the air, roving at will from flower to flower, sipping sweet honey from their cups, or basking in their sunny petals. If these little creatures knew how great a change awaited them, no doubt they would regret it; but would not all such sorrow be misplaced? And if that illustration will not move you, here is another:--We are children now; we feel as children, and we understand as children; and when we are told that men and women do not play with toys, and that our companions will one day weary of the trivial sports and occupations that interest them and us so deeply now, we cannot help being saddened at the thoughts of such an alteration, because we cannot conceive that as we grow up our own minds will become so enlarged and elevated that we ourselves shall then regard as trifling those objects and pursuits we now so fondly cherish, and that, though our companions will no longer join us in those childish pastimes, they will drink with us at other fountains of delight, and mingle their souls with ours in higher aims and nobler occupations beyond our present comprehension, but not less deeply relished or less truly good for that, while yet both we and they remain essentially the same individuals as before. But, Gilbert, can you really derive no consolation from the thought that we may meet together where there is no more pain and sorrow, no more striving against sin, and struggling of the spirit against the flesh; where both will behold the same glorious truths, and drink exalted and supreme felicity from the same fountain of light and goodness--that Being whom both will worship with the same intensity of holy ardour--and where pure and happy creatures both will love with the same divine affection? If you cannot, never write to me!'

`Helen, I can! if faith would never fail.'

`Now, then,' exclaimed she (Helen), `while this hope is strong within us--'

`We will part,' I cried. `You shall not have the pain of another effort to dismiss me. I will go at once; but--'

I did not put my request in words: she (Helen) understood it instinctively, and this time she (Helen) yielded too--or rather, there was nothing so deliberate as requesting or yielding in the matter: there was a sudden impulse that neither could resist. One moment I stood and looked into her (Helen) face, the next I held her (Helen) to my heart, and we seemed to grow together in a close embrace from which no physical or mental force could rend us. A whispered `God bless you!' and `Go--go!' was all she (Helen) said; but while she (Helen) spoke she (Helen) held me so fast that, without violence, I could not have obeyed her (Helen). At length, however, by some heroic effort, we tore ourselves apart, and I rushed from the house.

I have a confused remembrance of seeing little Arthur running up the garden-walk to meet me, and of bolting over the wall to avoid him (Arthur)--and subsequently running down the steep fields, clearing the stone fences and hedges as they came in my way, till I got completely out of sight of the old hall and down to the bottom of the hill; and then of long hours spent in bitter tears and lamentations, and melancholy musings in the lonely valley, with the eternal music in my ears, of the west wind rushing through the overshadowing trees, and the brook babbling and gurgling along its stony bed; my eyes, for the most part, vacantly fixed on the deep, chequered shades restlessly playing over the bright sunny grass at my feet, where now and then a withered leaf or two would come dancing to share the revelry; but my heart was away up the hill in that dark room where she (my) was weeping desolate and alone--she (my) whom I was not to comfort, not to see again, till years or suffering had overcome us both, and torn our spirits from their perishing abodes of clay.

There was little business done that day, you may be sure. The farm was abandoned to the labourers, and the labourers were left to their own devices. But one duty must be attended to; I had not forgotten my assault upon Frederick Lawrence; and I must see him (Lawrence) to apologise for the unhappy deed. I would fain have put it off till the morrow; but what if he (Lawrence) should denounce me to his (Lawrence) sister in the meantime? No, no! I must ask his (Lawrence) pardon to-day, and entreat him (Lawrence) to be lenient in his (Lawrence) accusation, if the revelation must be made. I deferred it, however, till the evening, when my spirits were more composed, and when--oh, wonderful perversity of human nature!--some faint germs of indefinite hopes were beginning to rise in my mind; not that I intended to cherish them, after all that had been said on the subject, but there they must lie for a while, uncrushed though not encouraged, till I had learnt to live without them.

Arrived at Woodford, the young squire's abode, I found no little difficulty in obtaining admission to his (squire) presence. The servant that opened the door told me his (squire) master was very ill, and seemed to think it doubtful whether he (squire) would be able to see me. I was not going to be baulked, however. I waited calmly in the hall to be announced, but inwardly determined to take no denial. The message was such as I expected--a polite intimation that Mr. Lawrence could see no one; he (Lawrence) was feverish, and must not be disturbed.

`I shall not disturb him (Lawrence) long,' said I; `but I must see him (Lawrence) for a moment: it is on business of importance that I wish to speak to him (Lawrence).'

`I'll tell him (Lawrence), sir,' said the man. And I advanced further into the hall and followed him (man) nearly to the door of the apartment where his (man) master was--for it seemed he (man) was not in bed. The answer returned was that Mr. Lawrence hoped I would be so good as to leave a message or a note with the servant, as he (servant) could attend to no business at present.

`He (servant) may as well see me as you,' said I; and, stepping past the astonished footman, I boldly rapped at the door, entered, and closed it behind me. The room was spacious and handsomely furnished--very comfortably, too, for a bachelor. A clear, red fire was burning in the polished grate: a superannuated greyhound, given up to idleness and good living, lay basking before it on the thick, soft rug, on one corner of which, beside the sofa, sat a smart young springer, looking wistfully up in its master's face--perhaps asking permission to share his (master) couch, or, it might be, only soliciting a caress from his (master) hand or a kind word from his (master) lips. The invalid himself looked very interesting as he (master) lay reclining there, in his (master) elegant dressing-gown, with a silk handkerchief bound across his (master) temples. His (master) usually pale face was flushed and feverish; his (master) eyes were half closed, until he (master) became sensible of my presence--and then he (master) opened them wide enough: one hand was thrown listlessly over the back of the sofa, and held a small volume, with which, apparently, he (master) had been vainly attempting to beguile the weary hours. He (master) dropped it, however, in his (master) start of indignant surprise as I advanced into the room and stood before him (master) on the rug. He (master) raised himself on his (master) pillows, and gazed upon me with equal degrees of nervous horror, anger, and amazement depicted on his (master) countenance.

`Mr. Markham, I scarcely expected this!' he (Markham) said; and the blood left his (Markham) cheek as he (Markham) spoke.

`I know you didn't,' answered I; `but be quiet a minute, and I'll tell you what I came for.' Unthinkingly, I advanced a step or two nearer. He (Markham) winced at my approach, with an expression of aversion and instinctive physical fear anything but conciliatory to my feelings. I stepped back, however.

`Make your story a short one,' said he (Markham), putting his (Markham) hand on the small silver bell that stood on the table beside him (Markham), `or I shall be obliged to call for assistance. I am in no state to bear your brutalities now, or your presence either.' And in truth the moisture started from his (Markham) pores and stood on his (Markham) pale forehead like dew.

Such a reception was hardly calculated to diminish the difficulties of my unenviable task. It must be performed however, in some fashion; and so I plunged into it at once, and floundered through it as I could.

`The truth is, Lawrence,' said I, `I have not acted quite correctly towards you of late--especially on this last occasion; and I'm come to--in short, to express my regret for what has been done, and to beg your pardon. If you don't choose to grant it,' I added hastily, not liking the aspect of his (Lawrence) face, `it's no matter; only I've done my duty--that's all.'

`It's easily done,' replied he (Lawrence), with a faint smile bordering on a sneer: `to abuse your friend and knock him (friend) on the head without any assignable cause, and then tell him (friend) the deed was not quite correct, but it's no matter whether he (friend) pardons it or not.'

`I forgot to tell you that it was in consequence of a mistake,'--muttered I. `I should have made a very handsome apology, but you provoked me so confoundedly with your--. Well, I suppose it's my fault. The fact is, I didn't know that you were Mrs. Graham's brother, and I saw and heard some things respecting your conduct towards her (Graham) which were calculated to awaken unpleasant suspicions, that, allow me to say, a little candour and confidence on your part might have removed; and, at last, I chanced to overhear a part of a conversation between you and her (Graham) that made me think I had a right to hate you.'

`And how came you to know that I was her (Graham) brother?' asked he (brother), in some anxiety.

`She (Graham) told me herself. She (Graham) told me all. She (Graham) knew I might be trusted. But you needn't disturb yourself about that, Mr. Lawrence, for I've seen the last of her (Graham)!'

`The last! Is she (Graham) gone, then?'

`No; but she (Graham) has bid adieu to me, and I have promised never to go near that house again while she (Graham) inhabits it.' I could have groaned aloud at the bitter thoughts awakened by this turn in the discourse. But I only clenched my hands and stamped my foot upon the rug. My companion, however, was evidently relieved.

`You have done right,' he (companion) said, in a tone of unqualified approbation, while his (companion) face brightened into almost a sunny expression. `And as for the mistake, I am sorry for both our sakes that it should have occurred. Perhaps you can forgive my want of candour, and remember, as some partial mitigation of the offence, how little encouragement to friendly confidence you have given me of late.'

`Yes, yes--I remember it all: nobody can blame me more than I blame myself in my own heart; at any rate, nobody can regret more sincerely than I do the result of my brutality, as you rightly term it.'

`Never mind that,' said he (me), faintly smiling; `let us forget all unpleasant words on both sides, as well as deeds, and consign to oblivion everything that we have cause to regret. Have you any objection to take my hand, or you'd rather not?' It trembled through weakness as he (me) held it out, and dropped before I had time to catch it and give it a hearty squeeze, which he (me) had not the strength to return.

`How dry and burning your hand is, Lawrence,' said I. `You are really ill, and I have made you worse by all this talk.'

`Oh, it is nothing; only a cold got by the rain.'

`My doing, too.'

`Never mind that. But tell me, did you mention this affair to my sister?'

`To confess the truth, I had not the courage to do so; but when you tell her (sister), will you just say that I deeply regret it, and--?'

`Oh, never fear! I shall say nothing against you, as long as you keep your good resolution of remaining aloof from her (sister). She (sister) has not heard of my illness, then, that you are aware of?'

`I think not.'

`I'm glad of that, for I have been all this time tormenting myself with the fear that somebody would tell her (sister) I was dying, or desperately ill, and she (sister) would be either distressing herself on account of her (sister) inability to hear from me or do me any good, or perhaps committing the madness of coming to see me. I must contrive to let her (sister) know something about it, if I can,' continued he (somebody), reflectively, `or she (sister) will be hearing some such story. Many would be glad to tell her (sister) such news, just to see how she (sister) would take it; and then she (sister) might expose herself to fresh scandal.'

`I wish I had told her (sister),' said I. `If it were not for my promise, I would tell her (sister) now.'

`By no means! I am not dreaming of that;--but if I were to write a short note, now, not mentioning you, Markham, but just giving a slight account of my illness, by way of excuse for my not coming to see her (sister), and to put her (sister) on her (sister) guard against any exaggerated reports she (sister) may hear,--and address it in a disguised hand--would you do me the favour to slip it into the post-office as you pass? for I dare not trust any of the servants in such a case.'

Most willingly I consented, and immediately brought him (guard) his (guard) desk. There was little need to disguise his (guard) hand, for the poor fellow seemed to have considerable difficulty in writing at all, so as to be legible. When the note was done, I thought it time to retire, and took leave, after asking if there was anything in the world I could do for him (guard), little or great, in the way of alleviating his (guard) sufferings, and repairing the injury I had done.

`No,' said he (guard); `you have already done much towards it; you have done more for me than the most skilful physician could do: for you have relieved my mind of two great burdens--anxiety on my sister's account, and deep regret upon your own: for I do believe these two sources of torment have had more effect in working me up into a fever than anything else; and I am persuaded I shall soon recover now. There is one more thing you can do for me, and that is, come and see me now and then--for you see I am very lonely here, and I promise your entrance shall not be disputed again.'

I engaged to do so, and departed with a cordial pressure of the hand. I posted the letter on my way home, most manfully resisting the temptation of dropping in a word from myself at the same time.

CHAPTER XLVI

I felt strongly tempted, at times, to enlighten my mother and sister on the real character and circumstances of the persecuted tenant of Wildfell Hall, and at first I greatly regretted having omitted to ask that lady's permission to do so; but, on due reflection, I considered that if it were known to them, it could not long remain a secret to the Millwards and Wilsons, and such was my present appreciation of Eliza Millward's disposition, that, if once she (Millward) got a clue to the story, I should fear she (Millward) would soon find means to enlighten Mr. Huntingdon upon the place of his (Huntingdon) wife's retreat. I would therefore wait patiently till these weary six months were over, and then, when the fugitive had found another home, and I was permitted to write to her (Millward), I would beg to be allowed to clear her (Millward) name from these vile calumnies: at present I must content myself with simply asserting that I knew them to be false, and would prove it some day, to the shame of those who slandered her (Millward). I don't think anybody believed me, but everybody soon learned to avoid insinuating a word against her (Millward), or even mentioning her (Millward) name in my presence. They thought I was so madly infatuated by the seductions of that unhappy lady that I was determined to support her (lady) in the very face of reason; and meantime I grow insupportably morose and misanthropical from the idea that every one I met was harbouring unworthy thoughts of the supposed Mrs. Graham, and would express them if he (them) dared. My poor mother was quite distressed about me; but I couldn't help it--at least I thought I could not, though sometimes I felt a pang of remorse for my undutiful conduct to her (mother), and made an effort to amend, attended with some partial success; and indeed I was generally more humanised in my demeanour to her (mother) than to any one else, Mr. Lawrence excepted. Rose and Fergus usually shunned my presence; and it was well they did, for I was not fit company for them, nor they for me, under the present circumstances.

Mrs. Huntingdon did not leave Wildfell Hall till above two months after our farewell interview. During that time she (Huntingdon) never appeared at church, and I never went near the house: I only knew she (Huntingdon) was still there by her (Huntingdon) brother's brief answers to my many and varied inquiries respecting her (Huntingdon). I was a very constant and attentive visitor to him (visitor) throughout the whole period of his (visitor) illness and convalescence; not only from the interest I took in his (visitor) recovery, and my desire to cheer him (visitor) up and make the utmost possible amends for my former `brutality,' but from my growing attachment to himself, and the increasing pleasure I found in his (visitor) society--partly from his (visitor) increased cordiality to me, but chiefly on account of his (visitor) close connection, both in blood and in affection, with my adored Helen. I loved him (visitor) for it better than I liked to express: and I took a secret delight in pressing those slender white fingers, so marvellously like her (Helen) own, considering he (visitor) was not a woman, and in watching the passing changes in his (visitor) fair, pale features, and observing the intonations of his (visitor) voice, detecting resemblances which I wondered had never struck me before. He (visitor) provoked me at times, indeed, by his (visitor) evident reluctance to talk to me about his (visitor) sister, though I did not question the friendliness of his (visitor) motives in wishing to discourage my remembrance of her (sister).

His (visitor) recovery was not quite so rapid as he (visitor) had expected it to be; he (visitor) was not able to mount his (visitor) pony till a fortnight after the date of our reconciliation; and the first use he (visitor) made of his (visitor) returning strength was to ride over by night to Wildfell Hall, to see his (visitor) sister. It was a hazardous enterprise both for him (visitor) and for her (sister), but he (visitor) thought it necessary to consult with her (sister) on the subject of her (sister) projected departure, if not to calm her (sister) apprehensions respecting his (visitor) health, and the worst result was a slight relapse of his (visitor) illness, for no one knew of the visit but the inmates of the old Hall, except myself; and I believe it had not been his (visitor) intention to mention it to me, for when I came to see him (visitor) the next day, and observed he (visitor) was not so well as he (visitor) ought to have been, he (visitor) merely said he (visitor) had caught cold by being out too late in the evening.

`You'll never be able to see your sister, if you don't take care of yourself,' said I, a little provoked at the circumstance on her (sister) account, instead of commiserating him (visitor).

`I've seen her (sister) already,' said he (visitor), quietly.

`You've seen her (sister)!' cried I, in astonishment.

`Yes.' And then he (visitor) told me what considerations had impelled him (visitor) to make the venture, and with what precautions he (visitor) had made it.

`And how was she (sister)?' I eagerly asked.

`As usual,' was the brief though sad reply.

`As usual--that is, far from happy and far from strong.'

`She (sister) is not positively ill,' returned he (visitor); `and she (sister) will recover her (sister) spirits in a while, I have no doubt--but so many trials have been almost too much for her (sister). How threatening those clouds look,' continued he (visitor), turning towards the window. `We shall have thunder-showers before night, I imagine, and they are just in the midst of stacking my corn. Have you got yours all in yet?'

`No. And, Lawrence, did she (sister)--did your sister mention me?'

`She (sister) asked if I had seen you lately.'

`And what else did she (sister) say?'

`I cannot tell you all she (sister) said,' replied he (Lawrence), with a slight smile; `for we talked a good deal, though my stay was but short; but our conversation was chiefly on the subject of her (sister) intended departure, which I begged her (sister) to delay till I was better able to assist her (sister) in her (sister) search after another home.'

`But did she (sister) say no more about me?'

`She (sister) did not say much about you, Markham. I should not have encouraged her (sister) to do so, had she (sister) been inclined; but happily she (sister) was not: she (sister) only asked a few questions concerning you, and seemed satisfied with my brief answers, wherein she (sister) showed herself wiser than her (sister) friend; and I may tell you, too, that she (sister) seemed to be far more anxious lest you should think too much of her (sister), than lest you should forget her (sister).'

`She (sister) was right.'

`But I fear your anxiety is quite the other way respecting her (sister).'

`No, it is not: I wish her (sister) to be happy; but I don't wish her (sister) to forget me altogether. She (sister) knows it is impossible that I should forget her (sister); and she (sister) is right to wish me not to remember her (sister) too well. I should not desire her (sister) to regret me too deeply; but I can scarcely imagine she (sister) will make herself very unhappy about me, because I know I am not worthy of it, except in my appreciation of her (sister).'

`You are neither of you worthy of a broken heart,--nor of all the sighs, and tears, and sorrowful thoughts that have been, and I fear will be, wasted upon you both; but, at present, each has a more exalted opinion of the other than, I fear, he (me) or she (sister) deserves; and my sister's feelings are naturally full as keen as yours, and I believe more constant; but she (sister) has the good sense and fortitude to strive against them in this particular; and I trust she (sister) will not rest till she (sister) has entirely weaned her (sister) thoughts--` he (me) hesitated.

`From me,' said I.

`And I wish you would make the like exertions,' continued he (me).

`Did she (sister) tell you that that was her (sister) intention?'

`No; the question was not broached between us: there was no necessity for it, for I had no doubt that such was her (sister) determination.'

`To forget me?'

`Yes, Markham! Why not?'

`Oh, well!' was my only audible reply; but I internally answered,--`No, Lawrence, you're wrong there: she (sister) is not determined to forget me. It would be wrong to forget one so deeply and fondly devoted to her (sister), who can so thoroughly appreciate her (sister) excellencies, and sympathise with all her (sister) thoughts, as I can do, and it would be wrong in me to forget so excellent and divine a piece of God's creation as she (sister), when I have once so truly loved and known her (sister).' But I said no more to him (God) on that subject. I instantly started a new topic of conversation, and soon took leave of my companion, with a feeling of less cordiality towards him (companion) than usual. Perhaps I had no right to be annoyed at him (companion), but I was so nevertheless.

In little more than a week after this I met him (companion) returning from a visit to the Wilsons'; and I now resolved to do him (companion) a good turn, though at the expense of his (companion) feelings, and perhaps at the risk of incurring that displeasure which is so commonly the reward of those who give disagreeable information, or tender their advice unasked. In this, believe me, I was actuated by no motives of revenge for the occasional annoyances I had lately sustained from him (companion),--nor yet by any feeling of malevolent enmity towards Miss Wilson, but purely by the fact that I could not endure that such a woman should be Mrs. Huntingdon's sister, and that, as well for his (companion) own sake as for hers, I could not bear to think of his (companion) being deceived into a union with one so unworthy of him (companion), and so utterly unfitted to be the partner of his (companion) quiet home, and the companion of his (companion) life. He (companion) had had uncomfortable suspicions on that head himself, I imagined; but such was his (companion) inexperience, and such were the lady's powers of attraction, and her (lady) skill in bringing them to bear upon his (companion) young imagination, that they had not disturbed him (companion) long; and I believe the only effectual causes of the vacillating indecision that had preserved him (companion) hitherto from making an actual declaration of love, was the consideration of her (lady) connections, and especially of her (lady) mother, whom he (companion) could not abide. Had they lived at a distance, he (companion) might have surmounted the objection, but within two or three miles of Woodford it was really no light matter.

`You've been to call on the Wilsons, Lawrence,' said I, as I walked beside his (Lawrence) pony.

`Yes,' replied he (Lawrence), slightly averting his (Lawrence) face: `I thought it but civil to take the first opportunity of returning their kind attentions, since they have been so very particular and constant in their inquiries throughout the whole course of my illness.'

`It's all Miss Wilson's doing.'

`And if it is,' returned he (Lawrence), with a very perceptible blush, `is that any reason why I should not make a suitable acknowledgment?'

`It is a reason why you should not make the acknowledgment she (Wilson) looks for.'

`Let us drop that subject if you please,' said he (Lawrence), in evident displeasure.

`No, Lawrence, with your leave we'll continue it a while longer; and I'll tell you something, now we're about it, which you may believe or not as you choose--only please to remember that it is not my custom to speak falsely, and that in this case I can have no motive for misrepresenting the truth--'

`Miss Wilson hates your sister. It may be natural enough that, in her (Wilson) ignorance of the relationship, she (Wilson) should feel some degree of enmity against her (Wilson), but no good or amiable woman would be capable of evincing that bitter, cold-blooded, designing malice towards a fancied rival that I have observed in her (woman).'

`Yes--and it is my belief that Eliza Millward and she (Millward), if not the very originators of the slanderous reports that have been propagated, were designedly the encouragers and chief disseminators of them. She (Millward) was not desirous to mix up your name in the matter, of course, but her (Millward) delight was, and still is, to blacken your sister's character to the utmost of her (Millward) power, without risking too greatly the exposure of her (Millward) own malevolence!'

`I cannot believe it,' interrupted my companion, his (companion) face burning with indignation.

`Well, as I cannot prove it, I must content myself with asserting that it is so to the best of my belief; but as you would not willingly marry Miss Wilson if it were so, you will do well to be cautious, till you have proved it to be otherwise.'

`I never told you, Markham, that I intended to marry Miss Wilson,' said he (Markham), proudly.

`No, but whether you do or not, she (Wilson) intends to marry you.'

`Did she (Wilson) tell you so?'

`Then you have no right to make such an assertion respecting her (Wilson).' He (Markham) slightly quickened his (Markham) pony's pace, but I laid my hand on its mane, determined he (Markham) should not leave me yet.

`Wait a moment, Lawrence, and let me explain myself; and don't be so very--I don't know what to call it--inaccessible as you are.--I know what you think of Jane Wilson; and I believe I know how far you are mistaken in your opinion: you think she (Wilson) is singularly charming, elegant, sensible, and refined: you are not aware that she (Wilson) is selfish, cold-hearted, ambitious, artful, shallow-minded--'

`Enough, Markham--enough!'

`No; let me finish:--you don't know that, if you married her (Wilson), your home would be rayless and comfortless; and it would break your heart at last to find yourself united to one so wholly incapable of sharing your tastes, feelings, and ideas--so utterly destitute of sensibility, good feeling, and true nobility of soul.'

`Have you done?' asked my companion quietly.

`Yes;--I know you hate me for my impertinence, but I don't care if it only conduces to preserve you from that fatal mistake.'

`Well!' returned he (companion), with a rather wintry smile--`I'm glad you have overcome or forgotten your own afflictions so far as to be able to study so deeply the affairs of others, and trouble your head so unnecessarily about the fancied or possible calamities of their future life.'

We parted--somewhat coldly again: but still we did not cease to be friends; and my well-meant warning, though it might have been more judiciously delivered, as well as more thankfully received, was not wholly unproductive of the desired effect: his (companion) visit to the Wilsons was not repeated, and though, in our subsequent interviews, he (companion) never mentioned her (friends) name to me, nor I to him (companion),--I have reason to believe he (companion) pondered my words in his (companion) mind, eagerly though covertly sought information respecting the fair lady from other quarters, secretly compared my character of her (lady) with what he (character) had himself observed and what he (character) heard from others, and finally came to the conclusion that, all things considered, she (lady) had much better remain Miss Wilson of Ryecote Farm than be transmuted into Mrs. Lawrence of Woodford Hall. I believe, too, that he (character) soon learned to contemplate with secret amazement his (character) former predilection, and to congratulate himself on the lucky escape he (character) had made; but he (character) never confessed it to me, or hinted one word of acknowledgment for the part I had had in his (character) deliverance, but this was not surprising to any one that knew him (character) as I did.

As for Jane Wilson, she (Lawrence), of course, was disappointed and embittered by the sudden cold neglect and ultimate desertion of her (Lawrence) former admirer. Had I done wrong to blight her (Lawrence) cherished hopes? I think not; and certainly my conscience has never accused me, from that day to this, of any evil design in the matter.

CHAPTER XLVII

One morning, about the beginning of November, while I was inditing some business letters, shortly after breakfast, Eliza Millward came to call upon my sister. Rose had neither the discrimination nor the virulence to regard the little demon as I did, and they still preserved their former intimacy. At the moment of her (Millward) arrival, however, there was no one in the room but Fergus and myself, my mother and sister being both of them absent, `on household cares intent'; but I was not going to lay myself out for her (mother) amusement, whoever else might so incline: I merely honoured her (mother) with a careless salutation and a few words of course, and then went on with my writing, leaving my brother to be more polite if he (brother) chose. But she (mother) wanted to tease me.

`What a pleasure it is to find you at home, Mr. Markham!' said she (mother), with a disingenuously malicious smile. `I so seldom see you now, for you never come to the vicarage. Papa, is quite offended, I can tell you,' she (mother) added playfully, looking into my face with an impertinent laugh, as she (mother) seated herself, half beside and half before my desk, off the corner of the table.

`I have had a good deal to do of late,' said I, without looking up from my letter.

`Have you, indeed! Somebody said you had been strangely neglecting your business these last few months.'

`Somebody said wrong, for, these last two months especially, I have been particularly plodding and diligent.'

`Ah! well, there's nothing like active employment, I suppose, to console the afflicted;--and, excuse me, Mr. Markham, but you look so very far from well, and have been, by all accounts, so moody and thoughtful of late,--I could almost think you have some secret care preying on your spirits. Formerly,' said she (I) timidly, `I could have ventured to ask you what it was, and what I could do to comfort you: I dare not do it now.'

`You're very kind, Miss Eliza. When I think you can do anything to comfort me, I'll make bold to tell you.'

`Pray do!--I suppose I mayn't guess what it is that troubles you?'

`There's no necessity, for I'll tell you plainly. The thing that troubles me the most at present is a young lady sitting at my elbow, and preventing me from finishing my letter, and, thereafter, repairing to my daily business.'

Before she (lady) could reply to this ungallant speech, Rose entered the room; and Miss Eliza rising to greet her (Eliza), they both seated themselves near the fire, where that idle lad Fergus was standing, leaning his (Fergus) shoulder against the corner of the chimney-piece, with his (Fergus) legs crossed and his (Fergus) hands in his (Fergus) breeches-pockets.

`Now, Rose, I'll tell you a piece of news--I hope you have not heard it before: for good, bad, or indifferent, one always likes to be the first to tell. It's about that sad Mrs. Graham--'

`Hush-sh-sh!' whispered Fergus, in a tone of solemn import. ```We never mention her (Graham); her (Graham) name is never heard.''' `I should be sorry to injure any one's feelings,' returned she (lady), speaking below her (lady) breath. `Another time, perhaps.'

`Well,' answered she (Eliza), `perhaps you know already that Mrs. Graham's husband is not really dead, and that she (Graham) had run away from him (husband)?' Only think,' she (Graham) continued, turning to the confounded Rose, `what a fool the man must be!'

`And who gave you this piece of intelligence, Miss Eliza?' said I, interrupting my sister's exclamations.

`I had it from a very authentic source.'

`From whom, may I ask?'

`From one of the servants at Woodford.'

`Oh! I was not aware that you were on such intimate terms with Mr. Lawrence's household.'

`It was not from the man himself that I heard it, but he (man) told it in confidence to our maid Sarah, and Sarah told it to me.'

`In confidence, I suppose? And you tell it in confidence to us? But I can tell you that it is but a lame story after all, and scarcely one-half of it true.'

While I spoke I completed the sealing and direction of my letters, with a somewhat unsteady hand, in spite of all my efforts to retain composure, and in spite of my firm conviction that the story was a lame one--that the supposed Mrs. Graham, most certainly, had not voluntarily gone back to her (Graham) husband, or dreamt of a reconciliation. Most likely she (Graham) was gone away, and the tale-bearing servant, not knowing what was become of her (Graham), had conjectured that such was the case, and our fair visitor had detailed it as a certainty, delighted with such an opportunity of tormenting me. `Yes, she (sister)'s gone,' was his (owner) answer, so calmly spoken that my terror was at once removed.

`I suppose I mayn't know where she (sister) is?' said I, as I dismounted, and relinquished my horse to the gardener, who, being the only servant within call, had been summoned by his (servant) master, from his (servant) employment of raking up the dead leaves on the lawn, to take him (servant) to the stables.

My companion gravely took my arm, and leading me away to the garden, thus answered my question,--`She (sister) is at Grassdale Manor, in --shire.'

`At Grassdale Manor.'

`Impossible, Lawrence! She (sister) could not be so frantic!' exclaimed I, vehemently grasping his (Lawrence) arm, as if to force him (Lawrence) to unsay those hateful words.

`She (sister) did,' persisted he (Lawrence) in the same grave, collected manner as before; `and not without reason,' he (Lawrence) continued, gently disengaging himself from my grasp. `Mr. Huntingdon is ill.'

`Yes.'

`I think not, Markham.'

I attempted no reply, for I was not sure that this circumstance did not partly conduce to my distraction. `Nothing persuaded her (sister) but her (sister) own sense of duty.'

`Humbug!'

`I was half inclined to say so myself, Markham, at first. `No,' replied he (man), `you may read it if you like.'

I read it, and so may you.

Grassdale, Nov. 4th.

DEAR FREDERICK,--I know you will be anxious to hear from me, and I will tell you all I can. Mr. Huntingdon is very ill, but not dying, or in any immediate danger; and he (Huntingdon) is rather better at present than he (Huntingdon) was when I came. I found the house in sad confusion: Mrs. Greaves, Benson, every decent servant had left, and those that were come to supply their places were a negligent, disorderly set, to say no worse--I must change them again, if I stay. A professional nurse, a grim, hard old woman, had been hired to attend the wretched invalid. He (servant) suffers much, and has no fortitude to bear him (servant) through. The immediate injuries he (servant) sustained from the accident, however, were not very severe, and would, as the doctor says, have been but trifling to a man of temperate habits, but with him (man) it is very different. On the night of my arrival, when I first entered his (man) room, he (man) was lying in a kind of half delirium. He (man) did not notice me till I spoke, and then he (man) mistook me for another.

`Is it you, Alice, come again?' he (man) murmured. `What did you leave me for?'

`It is I, Arthur--it is Helen, your wife,' I replied.

`My wife!' said he (Arthur), with a start. `For heaven's sake, don't mention her (wife)--I have none. Devil take her (wife),' he (Devil) cried, a moment after, `and you, too! What did you do it for?'

I said no more; but observing that he (Devil) kept gazing towards the foot of the bed, I went and sat there, placing the light so as to shine full upon me, for I thought he (Devil) might be dying, and I wanted him (Devil) to know me. For a long time he (Devil) lay silently looking upon me, first with a vacant stare, then with a fixed gaze of strange growing intensity. At last he (Devil) startled me by suddenly raising himself on his (Devil) elbow and demanding in a horrified whisper, with his (Devil) eyes still fixed upon me, `Who is it?'

`It is Helen Huntingdon,' said I, quietly rising at the same time, and removing to a less conspicuous position.

`I must be going mad,' cried he (Devil), `or something--delirious, perhaps; but leave me, whoever you are. I can't bear that white face, and those eyes. For God's sake go, and send me somebody else that doesn't look like that!'

I went at once, and sent the hired nurse; but next morning I ventured to enter his (God) chamber again, and, taking the nurse's place by his (God) bedside, I watched him (God) and waited on him (God) for several hours, showing myself as little as possible, and only speaking when necessary, and then not above my breath. `I mean to stay with you,' said I. And after that he (God) would call me Alice, or some other name almost equally repugnant to my feelings. I forced myself to endure it for a while, fearing a contradiction might disturb him (God) too much; but when, having asked for a glass of water, while I held it to his (God) lips, he (God) murmured, `Thanks, dearest!' I could swear at this moment that she (me) was by my side.'

`She (me) is,' said I.

`That seems comfortable,' continued he (God), without noticing my words; `and while you do it, the other fancies fade away--but this only strengthens.--Go on--go on, till it vanishes, too. I can't stand such a mania as this; it would kill me!'

`It never will vanish,' said I, distinctly, `for it is the truth!'

`The truth!' he (God) cried, starting, as if an asp had stung him (God). `You don't mean to say that you are really she (it)?'

`I do; but you needn't shrink away from me, as if I were your greatest enemy: I am come to take care of you, and do what none of them would do.'

`There are servants within call if you want them; but you had better lie down now and be quiet: none of them could or would attend you as carefully as I shall do.'

You need not fear to trust me: tell me all your wants, and I will try to satisfy them. There is no one else to care for you; and I shall not upbraid you now.'

All this may strike you as harsh, but I felt I must not lose my present advantage, and my son's future welfare should not be sacrificed to any mistaken tenderness for this man's feelings. Little Arthur had not forgotten his (Arthur) father, but thirteen months of absence, during which he (Arthur) had seldom been permitted to hear a word about him (Arthur), or hardly to whisper his (Arthur) name, had rendered him (Arthur) somewhat shy; and when he (Arthur) was ushered into the darkened room where the sick man lay, so altered from his (man) former self, with fiercely flushed face and wildly-gleaming eyes--he (man) instinctively clung to me, and stood looking on his (man) father with a countenance expressive of far more awe than pleasure.

`Yes.'

`Papa.'

`Yes.'

Next morning the doctor ordered him (doctor) to be bled; and after that he (doctor) was more subdued and tranquil. I passed half the day in his (doctor) room at different intervals. My presence did not appear to agitate or irritate him (doctor) as before, and he (doctor) accepted my services quietly, without any bitter remarks: indeed, he (doctor) scarcely spoke at all, except to make known his (doctor) wants, and hardly then. `Oh, this sweet revenge!' cried he (doctor), when I had been doing all I could to make him (doctor) comfortable and to remedy the carelessness of his (doctor) nurse. `And you can enjoy it with such a quiet conscience too, because it's all in the way of duty.'

`It is well for me that I am doing my duty,' said I, with a bitterness I could not repress, `for it is the only comfort I have; and the satisfaction of my own conscience, it seems, is the only reward I need look for!'

He (doctor) looked rather surprised at the earnestness of my manner.

`What reward did you look for?' he (doctor) asked.

`You will think me a liar if I tell you; but I did hope to benefit you: as well to better your mind as to alleviate your present sufferings; but it appears I am to do neither; your own bad spirit will not let me. As far as you are concerned, I have sacrificed my own feelings, and all the little earthly comfort that was left me, to no purpose; and every little thing I do for you is ascribed to self-righteous malice and refined revenge!'

`It's all very fine, I daresay,' said he (I), eyeing me with stupid amazement; `and of course I ought to be melted to tears of penitence and admiration at the sight of so much generosity and superhuman goodness; but you see I can't manage it. However, pray do me all the good you can, if you do really find any pleasure in it; for you perceive I am almost as miserable just now as you need wish to see me. Since you came, I confess, I have had better attendance than before, for these wretches neglected me shamefully, and all my old friends seem to have fairly forsaken me. I've had a dreadful time of it, I assure you: I sometimes thought I should have died: do you think there's any chance?'

`There's always a chance of death; and it is always well to live with such a chance in view.'

`Yes, yes! but do you think there's any likelihood that this illness will have a fatal termination?'

`I cannot tell; but, supposing it should, how are you prepared to meet the event?'

`Why, the doctor told me I wasn't to think about it, for I was sure to get better if I stuck to his (doctor) regimen and prescriptions.'

`I hope you may, Arthur; but neither the doctor nor I can speak with certainty in such a case; there is internal injury, and it is difficult to know to what extent.'

`There now! you want to scare me to death.'

`No; but I don't want to lull you to false security. If a consciousness of the uncertainty of life can dispose you to serious and useful thoughts, I would not deprive you of the benefit of such reflections, whether you do eventually recover or not. Does the idea of death appal you very much?'

`It's just the only thing I can't bear to think of; so if you've any--'

`But it must come some time,' interrupted I, `and if it be years hence, it will as certainly overtake you as if it came to-day,--and no doubt be as unwelcome then as now, unless you--'

`Oh, hang it! don't torment me with your preachments now, unless you want to kill me outright. I can't stand it, I tell you. I've sufferings enough without that. If you think there's danger, save me from it; and then, in gratitude, I'll hear whatever you like to say.'

I accordingly dropped the unwelcome topic. And now, Frederick, I think I may bring my letter to a close. From these details you may form your own judgment of the state of my patient, and of my own position and future prospects. Let me hear from you soon, and I will write again to tell you how we get on; but now that my presence is tolerated, and even required, in the sick-room, I shall have but little time to spare between my husband and my son,--for I must not entirely neglect the latter: it would not do to keep him (son) always with Rachel, and I dare not leave him (son) for a moment with any of the other servants, or suffer him (son) to be alone, lest he (son) should meet them. If his (son) father get worse, I shall ask Esther Hargrave to take charge of him (son) for a time, till I have reorganised the household at least; but I greatly prefer keeping him (son) under my own eye.

I find myself in rather a singular position: I am exerting my utmost endeavours to promote the recovery and reformation of my husband, and if I succeed, what shall I do? My duty, of course,--but how? No matter; I can perform the task that is before me now, and God will give me strength to do whatever He (God) requires hereafter. Good-by, dear Frederick.

HELEN HUNTINGDON.

`What do you think of it?' said Lawrence, as I silently refolded the letter.

`If all be well, I'll come myself and tell you immediately.'

CHAPTER XLVIII

Five or six days after this Mr. Lawrence paid us the honour of a call; and when he (Lawrence) and I were alone together--which I contrived as soon as possible by bringing him (Lawrence) out to look at my cornstacks--he (Lawrence) showed me another letter from his (Lawrence) sister. This one he (Lawrence) was quite willing to submit to my longing gaze; he (Lawrence) thought, I suppose, it would do me good. The only answer it gave to my message was this:--

`Mr. Markham is at liberty to make such revelations concerning me as he (Markham) judges necessary. He (Markham) will know that I should wish but little to be said on the subject. I hope he (Markham) is well; but tell him (Markham) he (Markham) must not think of me.'

I can give you a few extracts from the rest of the letter, for I was permitted to keep this also--perhaps, as an antidote to all pernicious hopes and fancies.

* * * * *

He (Markham) is decidedly better, but very low from the depressing effects of his (Markham) severe illness and the strict regimen he (Markham) is obliged to observe--so opposite to all his (Markham) previous habits. It is deplorable to see how completely his (Markham) past life has degenerated his (Markham) once noble constitution, and vitiated the whole system of his (Markham) organization. But the doctor says he (Markham) may now be considered out of danger, if he (Markham) will only continue to observe the necessary restrictions. Some stimulating cordials he (Markham) must have, but they should be judiciously diluted and sparingly used; and I find it very difficult to keep him (Markham) to this. At first, his (Markham) extreme dread of death rendered the task an easy one; but in proportion as he (Markham) feels his (Markham) acute suffering abating, and sees the danger receding, the more intractable he (Markham) becomes. Now, also, his (Markham) appetite for food is beginning to return; and here, too, his (Markham) long habits of self-indulgence are greatly against him (Markham). I watch and restrain him (Markham) as well as I can, and often get bitterly abused for my rigid severity; and sometimes he (Markham) contrives to elude my vigilance, and sometimes acts in opposition to my will. But he (Markham) is now so completely reconciled to my attendance in general that he (Markham) is never satisfied when I am not by his (Markham) side. I am obliged to be a little stiff with him (Markham) sometimes, or he (Markham) would make a complete slave of me; and I know it would be unpardonable weakness to give up all other interests for him (Markham). I did not look at it; and had it rolled quietly by me, I should not have remembered the fact of its appearance at all; but a tiny voice from within it roused me by exclaiming, `Mamma, mamma, here's Mr. Markham!'

I did not hear the reply, but presently the same voice answered, `It is indeed, mamma--look for yourself.'

I did not raise my eyes, but I suppose mamma looked, for a clear melodious voice, whose tones thrilled through my nerves, exclaimed, `Oh, aunt! here's Mr. Markham, Arthur's friend! Stop, Richard!'

There was such evidence of joyous though suppressed excitement in the utterance of those few words--especially that tremulous, `Oh, aunt'--that it threw me almost off my guard. The carriage stopped immediately, and I looked up and met the eye of a pale, grave, elderly lady surveying me from the open window. She (lady) bowed, and so did I, and then she (lady) withdrew her (lady) head, while Arthur screamed to the footman to let him (Arthur) out; but before that functionary could descend from his (Arthur) box a hand was silently put forth from the carriage window. I knew that hand, though a black glove concealed its delicate whiteness and half its fair proportions, and quickly seizing it, I pressed it in my own--ardently for a moment, but instantly recollecting myself, I dropped it, and it was immediately withdrawn.

`Were you coming to see us, or only passing by?' asked the low voice of its owner, who, I felt, was attentively surveying my countenance from behind the thick black veil which, with the shadowing panels, entirely concealed her (it) own from me.

`I--I came to see the place,' faltered I.

`The place,' repeated she (it), in a tone which betokened more displeasure or disappointment than surprise.

`Will you not enter it, then?'

`If you wish it.'

`Can you doubt?'

`Yes, yes! he (owner) must enter,' cried Arthur, running round from the other door; and seizing my hand in both his (Arthur), he (Arthur) shook it heartily.

`Do you remember me, sir?' said he (Arthur).

`Yes, full well, my little man, altered though you are,' replied I, surveying the comparatively tall, slim young gentleman, with his (gentleman) mother's image visibly stamped upon his (gentleman) fair, intelligent features, in spite of the blue eyes beaming with gladness, and the bright locks clustering beneath his (gentleman) cap.

`Am I not grown?' said he (gentleman), stretching himself up to his (gentleman) full height.

`Grown! three inches, upon my word!'

`I was seven last birthday,' was the proud rejoinder. `In seven years more I shall be as tall as you nearly.'

`Arthur,' said his (Arthur) mother, `tell him (Arthur) to come in. Go on, Richard.'

There was a touch of sadness as well as coldness in her (mother) voice, but I knew not to what to ascribe it. The carriage drove on and entered the gates before us. My little companion led me up the park, discoursing merrily all the way. Arrived at the hall-door, I paused on the steps and looked round me, waiting to recover my composure, if possible--or, at any rate, to remember my new-formed resolutions and the principles on which they were founded; and it was not till Arthur had been for some time gently pulling my coat, and repeating his (Arthur) invitations to enter, that I at length consented to accompany him (Arthur) into the apartment where the ladies awaited us.

Helen eyed me as I entered with a kind of gentle, serious scrutiny, and politely asked after Mrs. Markham and Rose. I respectfully answered her (Markham) inquiries. Mrs. Maxwell begged me to be seated, observing it was rather cold, but she (Maxwell) supposed I had not travelled far that morning.

`Not quite twenty miles,' I answered.

`Not on foot!'

`No, Madam, by coach.'

`Here's Rachel, sir,' said Arthur, the only truly happy one amongst us, directing my attention to that worthy individual, who had just entered to take her (Rachel) mistress's things. She (Rachel) vouchsafed me an almost friendly smile of recognition--a favour that demanded, at least, a civil salutation on my part, which was accordingly given and respectfully returned--she (Rachel) had seen the error of her (Rachel) former estimation of my character.

When Helen was divested of her (Helen) lugubrious bonnet and veil, her (Helen) heavy winter cloak, &c., she (Helen) looked so like herself that I knew not how to bear it. I was particularly glad to see her (Helen) beautiful black hair, unstinted still, and unconcealed in its glossy luxuriance.

`Mamma has left off her (Helen) widow's cap in honour of uncle's marriage,' observed Arthur, reading my looks with a child's mingled simplicity and quickness of observation. Mamma looked grave and Mrs. Maxwell shook her (Maxwell) head. `And aunt Maxwell is never going to leave off hers,' persisted the naughty boy; but when he (boy) saw that his (boy) pertness was seriously displeasing and painful to his (boy) aunt, he (boy) went and silently put his (boy) arm round her (aunt) neck, kissed her (aunt) cheek, and withdrew to the recess of one of the great bay-windows, where he (boy) quietly amused himself with his (boy) dog, while Mrs. Maxwell gravely discussed with me the interesting topics of the weather, the season, and the roads. I considered her (Maxwell) presence very useful as a check upon my natural impulses--an antidote to those emotions of tumultuous excitement which would otherwise have carried me away against my reason and my will; but just then I felt the restraint almost intolerable, and I had the greatest difficulty in forcing myself to attend to her (Maxwell) remarks and answer them with ordinary politeness; for I was sensible that Helen was standing within a few feet of me beside the fire. I dared not look at her (Helen), but I felt her (Helen) eye was upon me, and from one hasty, furtive glance, I thought her (Helen) cheek was slightly flushed, and that her (Helen) fingers, as she (Helen) played with her (Helen) watch-chain, were agitated with that restless, trembling motion which betokens high excitement.

`Tell me,' said she (Helen), availing herself of the first pause in the attempted conversation between her (Helen) aunt and me, and speaking fast and low, with her (Helen) eyes bent on the gold chain--for I now ventured another glance--`Tell me how you all are at Linden-hope--has nothing happened since I left you?'

`I believe not.'

`Nobody dead? nobody married?'

`No.'

`Or--or expecting to marry?--No old ties dissolved or new ones formed? no old friends forgotten or supplanted?'

She (Helen) dropped her (Helen) voice so low in the last sentence that no one could have caught the concluding words but myself, and at the same time turned her (Helen) eyes upon me with a dawning smile, most sweetly melancholy, and a look of timid though keen inquiry that made my cheeks tingle with inexpressible emotions.

`I believe not,' I answered. `Certainly not, if others are as little changed as I.' Her (Helen) face glowed in sympathy with mine.

`And you really did not mean to call?' she (Helen) exclaimed.

`I feared to intrude.'

`To intrude!' cried she (Helen), with an impatient gesture. `What--` but as if suddenly recollecting her (Helen) aunt's presence, she (Helen) checked herself, and, turning to that lady, continued--`Why, aunt, this man is my brother's close friend, and was my own intimate acquaintance -LRB-for a few short months at least-RRB-, and professed a great attachment to my boy--and when he (boy) passes the house, so many scores of miles from his (boy) home, he (boy) declines to look in for fear of intruding!'

`Mr. Markham is over-modest,' observed Mrs. Maxwell.

`Over-ceremonious rather,' said her (Maxwell) niece--`over--well, it's no matter.' And turning from me, she (Maxwell) seated herself in a chair beside the table, and pulling a book to her (Maxwell) by the cover, began to turn over the leaves in an energetic kind of abstraction.

`If I had known,' said I, `that you would have honoured me by remembering me as an intimate acquaintance, I most likely should not have denied myself the pleasure of calling upon you, but I thought you had forgotten me long ago.'

`You judged of others by yourself,' muttered she (Maxwell) without raising her (Maxwell) eyes from the book, but reddening as she (Maxwell) spoke, and hastily turning over a dozen leaves at once.

There was a pause, of which Arthur thought he (Arthur) might venture to avail himself to introduce his (Arthur) handsome young setter, and show me how wonderfully it was grown and improved, and to ask after the welfare of its father Sancho. Mrs. Maxwell then withdrew to take off her (Maxwell) things. Helen immediately pushed the book from her (Helen), and after silently surveying her (Helen) son, his (son) friend, and his (son) dog for a few moments, she (Helen) dismissed the former from the room under pretence of wishing him (son) to fetch his (son) last new book to show me. The child obeyed with alacrity; but I continued caressing the dog. The silence might have lasted till its master's return, had it depended on me to break it; but, in half a minute or less, my hostess impatiently rose, and, taking her (hostess) former station on the rug between me and the chimney corner, earnestly exclaimed--

`Gilbert, what is the matter with you?--why are you so changed? It is a very indiscreet question, I know,' she (hostess) hastened to add: `perhaps a very rude one--don't answer it if you think so--but I hate mysteries and concealments.'

`I am not changed, Helen--unfortunately I am as keen and passionate as ever--it is not I, it is circumstances that are changed.'

`What circumstances? Do tell me!' Her (Helen) cheek was blanched with the very anguish of anxiety--could it be with the fear that I had rashly pledged my faith to another?

`I'll tell you at once,' said I. `I will confess that I came here for the purpose of seeing you -LRB-not without some monitory misgivings at my own presumption, and fears that I should be as little welcome as expected when I came-RRB-, but I did not know that this estate was yours until enlightened on the subject of your inheritance by the conversation of two fellow-passengers in the last stage of my journey; and then I saw at once the folly of the hopes I had cherished, and the madness of retaining them a moment longer; and though I alighted at your gates, I determined not to enter within them; I lingered a few minutes to see the place, but was fully resolved to return to M-- without seeing its mistress.'

`And if my aunt and I had not been just returning from our morning drive, I should have seen and heard no more of you?'

`I thought it would be better for both that we should not meet,' replied I, as calmly as I could, but not daring to speak above my breath, from conscious inability to steady my voice, and not daring to look in her (aunt) face lest my firmness should forsake me altogether. `I thought an interview would only disturb your peace and madden me. But I am glad, now, of this opportunity of seeing you once more and knowing that you have not forgotten me, and of assuring you that I shall never cease to remember you.'

There was a moment's pause. Mrs. Huntingdon moved away, and stood in the recess of the window. Did she (Huntingdon) regard this as an intimation that modesty alone prevented me from asking her (Huntingdon) hand? and was she (Huntingdon) considering how to repulse me with the smallest injury to my feelings? Before I could speak to relieve her (Huntingdon) from such a perplexity, she (Huntingdon) broke the silence herself by suddenly turning towards me and observing--

`You might have had such an opportunity before--as far, I mean, as regards assuring me of your kindly recollections, and yourself of mine, if you had written to me.'

`I would have done so, but I did not know your address, and did not like to ask your brother, because I thought he (brother) would object to my writing; but this would not have deterred me for a moment, if I could have ventured to believe that you expected to hear from me, or even wasted a thought upon your unhappy friend; but your silence naturally led me to conclude myself forgotten.'

`Did you expect me to write to you, then?'

`No, Helen--Mrs. Huntingdon,' said I, blushing at the implied imputation, `certainly not; but if you had sent me a message through your brother, or even asked him (brother) about me now and then--'

`I did ask about you frequently. I was not going to do more,' continued she (Huntingdon), smiling, `so long as you continued to restrict yourself to a few polite inquiries about my health.'

`Your brother never told me that you had mentioned my name.'

`Did you ever ask him (brother)?'

`No; for I saw he (brother) did not wish to be questioned about you, or to afford the slightest encouragement or assistance to my too obstinate attachment.' Helen did not reply. `And he (brother) was perfectly right,' added I. But she (Helen) remained in silence, looking out upon the snowy lawn. `Oh, I will relieve her (Helen) of my presence,' thought I; and immediately I rose and advanced to take leave, with a most heroic resolution--but pride was at the bottom of it, or it could not have carried me through.

`Are you going already?' said she (Helen), taking the hand I offered, and not immediately letting it go.

`Why should I stay any longer?'

`Wait till Arthur comes, at least.'

Only too glad to obey, I stood and leant against the opposite side of the window.

`You told me you were not changed,' said my companion: `you are--very much so.'

`No, Mrs. Huntingdon, I only ought to be.'

`Do you mean to maintain that you have the same regard for me that you had when last we met?'

`I have; but it would be wrong to talk of it now.'

`It was wrong to talk of it then, Gilbert; it would not now--unless to do so would be to violate the truth.'

I was too much agitated to speak; but, without waiting for an answer, she (Huntingdon) turned away her (Huntingdon) glistening eye and crimson cheek, and threw up the window and looked out, whether to calm her (Huntingdon) own, excited feelings, or to relieve her (Huntingdon) embarrassment, or only to pluck that beautiful half-blown Christmas-rose that grew upon the little shrub without, just peeping from the snow that had hitherto, no doubt, defended it from the frost, and was now melting away in the sun. Pluck it, however, she (Huntingdon) did, and having gently dashed the glittering powder from its leaves, approached it to her (Huntingdon) lips and said:

`This rose is not so fragrant as a summer flower, but it has stood through hardships none of them could bear: the cold rain of winter has sufficed to nourish it, and its faint sun to warm it; the bleak winds have not blanched it, or broken its stem, and the keen frost has not blighted it. Look, Gilbert, it is still fresh and blooming as a flower can be, with the cold snow even now on its petals.--Will you have it?'

I held out my hand: I dared not speak lest my emotion should overmaster me. She (its) laid the rose across my palm, but I scarcely closed my fingers upon it, so deeply was I absorbed in thinking what might be the meaning of her (its) words, and what I ought to do or say upon the occasion; whether to give way to my feelings or restrain them still. Misconstruing this hesitation into indifference--or reluctance even--to accept her (its) gift, Helen suddenly snatched it from my hand, threw it out on to the snow, shut down the window with an emphasis, and withdrew to the fire.

`Helen, what means this?' I cried, electrified at this startling change in her (Helen) demeanour.

`You did not understand my gift,' said she (Helen)--`or, what is worse, you despised it. I'm sorry I gave it you; but since I did make such a mistake, the only remedy I could think of was to take it away.'

`You misunderstood me cruelly,' I replied, and in a minute I had opened the window again, leaped out, picked up the flower, brought it in, and presented it to her (Helen), imploring her (Helen) to give it me again, and I would keep it for ever for her (Helen) sake, and prize it more highly than anything in the world I possessed.

`And will this content you?' said she (Helen), as she (Helen) took it in her (Helen) hand.

`It shall,' I answered.

`There, then; take it.'

I pressed it earnestly to my lips, and put it in my bosom, Mrs. Huntingdon looking on with a half-sarcastic smile.

`Now, are you going?' said she (Huntingdon).

`I will if--if I must.'

`You are changed,' persisted she (Huntingdon)--`you are grown either very proud or very indifferent.'

`I am neither, Helen--Mrs. Huntingdon. If you could see my heart--'

`You must be one,--if not both. And why Mrs. Huntingdon?--why not Helen, as before?'

`Helen, then--dear Helen!' I murmured. I was in an agony of mingled love, hope, delight, uncertainty, and suspense.

`The rose I gave you was an emblem of my heart,' said she (Helen); `would you take it away and leave me here alone?'

`Would you give me your hand too, if I asked it?'

`Have I not said enough?' she (Helen) answered, with a most enchanting smile. I snatched her (Helen) hand, and would have fervently kissed it, but suddenly checked myself, and said,--

`But have you considered the consequences?'

`Hardly, I think, or I should not have offered myself to one too proud to take me, or too indifferent to make his (it) affection outweigh my worldly goods.'

Stupid blockhead that I was!--I trembled to clasp her (Helen) in my arms, but dared not believe in so much joy, and yet restrained myself to say,--

`But if you should repent!'

`It would be your fault,' she (Helen) replied: `I never shall, unless you bitterly disappoint me. If you have not sufficient confidence in my affection to believe this, let me alone.'

`My darling angel--my own Helen,' cried I, now passionately kissing the hand I still retained, and throwing my left arm around her (Helen), `you never shall repent, if it depend on me alone. But have you thought of your aunt?' I trembled for the answer, and clasped her (aunt) closer to my heart in the instinctive dread of losing my new-found treasure.

`My aunt must not know of it yet,' said she (aunt). `She (aunt) would think it a rash, wild step, because she (aunt) could not imagine how well I know you; but she (aunt) must know you herself, and learn to like you. You must leave us now, after lunch, and come again in spring, and make a longer stay, and cultivate her (aunt) acquaintance, and I know you will like each other.'

`And then you will be mine,' said I, printing a kiss upon her (aunt) lips, and another, and another; for I was as daring and impetuous now as I had been backward and constrained before.

`No--in another year,' replied she (aunt), gently disengaging herself from my embrace, but still fondly clasping my hand.

`Another year! Oh, Helen, I could not wait so long!'

`Where is your fidelity?'

`I mean I could not endure the misery of so long a separation.'

`It would not be a separation: we will write every day: my spirit shall be always with you, and sometimes you shall see me with your bodily eye. I will not be such a hypocrite as to pretend that I desire to wait so long myself, but as my marriage is to please myself, alone, I ought to consult my friends about the time of it.'

`Your friends will disapprove.'

`They will not greatly disapprove, dear Gilbert,' said she (you), earnestly kissing my hand; `they cannot, when they know you, or, if they could, they would not be true friends--I should not care for their estrangement. Now are you satisfied?' She (you) looked up in my face with a smile of ineffable tenderness.

`Can I be otherwise, with your love? And you do love me, Helen?' said I, not doubting the fact, but wishing to hear it confirmed by her (Helen) own acknowledgment. `If you loved as I do,' she (Helen) earnestly replied, `you would not have so nearly lost me--these scruples of false delicacy and pride would never thus have troubled you--you would have seen that the greatest worldly distinctions and discrepancies of rank, birth, and fortune are as dust in the balance compared with the unity of accordant thoughts and feelings, and truly loving, sympathising hearts and souls.'

`But this is too much happiness,' said I, embracing her (Helen) again; `I have not deserved it, Helen--I dare not believe in such felicity: and the longer I have to wait, the greater will be my dread that something will intervene to snatch you from me--and think, a thousand things may happen in a year!--I shall be in one long fever of restless terror and impatience all the time. And besides, winter is such a dreary season.'

`I thought so too,' replied she (Helen) gravely: `I would not be married in winter--in December, at least,' she (Helen) added, with a shudder--for in that month had occurred both the ill-starred marriage that had bound her (Helen) to her (Helen) former husband, and the terrible death that released her (Helen)--`and therefore I said another year, in spring.'

`Next spring?'

`No, no--next autumn, perhaps.'

`Summer, then?'

`Well, the close of summer. There now! be satisfied.'

While she (Helen) was speaking Arthur re-entered the room--good boy for keeping out so long.

`Mamma, I couldn't find the book in either of the places you told me to look for it' -LRB-there was a conscious something in mamma's smile that seemed to say, `No, dear, I knew you could not'-RRB-, `but Rachel got it for me at last. Look, Mr. Markham, a natural history, with all kinds of birds and beasts in it, and the reading as nice as the pictures!'

In great good humour I sat down to examine the book, and drew the little fellow between my knees. Had he (fellow) come a minute before I should have received him (fellow) less graciously, but now I affectionately stroked his (fellow) curling looks, and even kissed his (fellow) ivory forehead: he (fellow) was my own Helen's son, and therefore mine; and as such I have ever since regarded him (fellow). That pretty child is now a fine young man: he (man) has realised his (man) mother's brightest expectations, and is at present residing in Grassdale Manor with his (man) young wife--the merry little Helen Hattersley of yore.

I had not looked through half the book before Mrs. Maxwell appeared to invite me into the other room to lunch. That lady's cool, distant manners rather chilled me at first; but I did my best to propitiate her (lady), and not entirely without success, I think, even in that first short visit; for when I talked cheerfully to her (lady), she (lady) gradually became more kind and cordial, and when I departed she (lady) bade me a gracious adieu, hoping ere long to have the pleasure of seeing me again.

`But you must not go till you have seen the conservatory, my aunt's winter garden,' said Helen, as I advanced to take leave of her (Helen), with as much philosophy and self-command as I could summon to my aid.

I gladly availed myself of such a respite, and followed her (Helen) into a large and beautiful conservatory, plentifully furnished with flowers, considering the season--but, of course, I had little attention to spare for them. It was not, however, for any tender colloquy that my companion had brought me there:--

`My aunt is particularly fond of flowers,' she (aunt) observed, `and she (aunt) is fond of Staningley too: I brought you here to offer a petition in her (aunt) behalf, that this may be her (aunt) home as long as she (aunt) lives, and--if it be not our home likewise--that I may often see her (aunt) and be with her (aunt); for I fear she (aunt) will be sorry to lose me; and though she (aunt) leads a retired and contemplative life, she (aunt) is apt to get low-spirited if left too much alone.'

`By all means, dearest Helen!--do what you will with your own. I should not dream of wishing your aunt to leave the place under any circumstances; and we will live either here or elsewhere as you and she (aunt) may determine, and you shall see her (aunt) as often as you like. I know she (aunt) must be pained to part with you, and I am willing to make any reparation in my power. I love her (aunt) for your sake, and her (aunt) happiness shall be as dear to me as that of my own mother.'

`Thank you, darling! you shall have a kiss for that. Good-by. There now--there, Gilbert--let me go--here's Arthur; don't astonish his (Arthur) infantile brain with your madness.'

* * * * *

But it is time to bring my narrative to a close. Any one but you would say I had made it too long already. But for your satisfaction I will add a few words more; because I know you will have a fellow-feeling for the old lady, and will wish to know the last of her (lady) history. I did come again in spring, and, agreeably to Helen's injunctions, did my best to cultivate her (Helen) acquaintance. She (Helen) received me very kindly, having been, doubtless, already prepared to think highly of my character by her (Helen) niece's too favourable report. I turned my best side out, of course, and we got along marvellously well together. When my ambitious intentions were made known to her (Helen), she (Helen) took it more sensibly than I had ventured to hope. Her (Helen) only remark on the subject, in my hearing, was--

`And so, Mr. Markham, you are going to rob me of my niece, I understand. Well! I hope God will prosper your union, and make my dear girl happy at last. Could she (girl) have been contented to remain single, I own I should have been better satisfied; but if she (girl) must marry again, I know of no one, now living and of a suitable age, to whom I would more willingly resign her (girl) than yourself, or who would be more likely to appreciate her (girl) worth and make, her (girl) truly happy, as far as I can tell.'

Of course I was delighted with the compliment, and hoped to show her (girl) that she (girl) was not mistaken in her (girl) favourable judgment.

`I have, however, one request to offer,' continued she (girl). `It seems I am still to look on Staningley as my home: I wish you to make it yours likewise, for Helen is attached to the place and to me--as I am to her (Helen). There are painful associations connected with Grassdale, which she (Helen) cannot easily overcome; and I shall not molest you with my company or interference here: I am a very quiet person, and shall keep my own apartments, and attend to my own concerns, and only see you now and then.'

Of course I most readily consented to this; and we lived in the greatest harmony with our dear aunt until the day of her (aunt) death, which melancholy event took place a few years after--melancholy, not to herself -LRB-for it came quietly upon her (aunt), and she (aunt) was glad to reach her (aunt) journey's end-RRB-, but only to the few loving friends and grateful dependents she (aunt) left behind.

To return, however, to my own affairs: I was married in summer, on a glorious August morning. It took the whole eight months, and all Helen's kindness and goodness to boot, to overcome my mother's prejudices against my bride-elect, and to reconcile her (mother) to the idea of my leaving Linden Grange and living so far away. Yet she (mother) was gratified at her (mother) son's good fortune after all, and proudly attributed it all to his (son) own superior merits and endowments. I bequeathed the farm to Fergus, with better hopes of its prosperity than I should have had a year ago under similar circumstances; for he (Fergus) had lately fallen in love with the Vicar of L--'s eldest daughter--a lady whose superiority had roused his (Vicar) latent virtues, and stimulated him (Vicar) to the most surprising exertions, not only to gain her (lady) affection and esteem, and to obtain a fortune sufficient to aspire to her (lady) hand, but to render himself worthy of her (lady), in his (Vicar) own eyes, as well as in those of her (lady) parents; and in the end he (Vicar) was successful, as you already know. As for myself, I need not tell you how happily my Helen and I have lived together, and how blessed we still are in each other's society, and in the promising young scions that are growing up about us. We are just now looking forward to the advent of you and Rose, for the time of your annual visit draws nigh, when you must leave your dusty, smoky, noisy, toiling, striving city for a season of invigorating relaxation and social retirement with us.

Till then, farewell, GILBERT MARKHAM.

STANINGLEY: _June_ 10_th_, 1847.

THE END
